Accordingly I wrote to Professor Miller, of Cambridge, and this geomete has kindly read over the following statement, drawn up from hi information, and tells me that it is strictly correct: If a number of equal spheres be described with their centres placed in tw parallel layers; with the centre of each sphere at the distance of radius  sqrt(2) or radius x 1.41421 (or at some lesser distance), from the centre of the six surrounding spheres in the same layer; and at the same distanc from the centres of the adjoining spheres in the other and parallel layer then, if planes of intersection between the several spheres in both layer be formed, there will result a double layer of hexagonal prisms unite together by pyramidal bases formed of three rhombs; and the rhombs and th sides of the hexagonal prisms will have every angle identically the sam with the best measurements which have been made of the cells of th hive-bee.

As according to the theory of natural selection an interminable number o intermediate forms must have existed, linking together all the species i each group by gradations as fine as our existing varieties, it may b asked, Why do we not see these linking forms all around us?  Why are no all organic beings blended together in an inextricable chaos?  With respec to existing forms, we should remember that we have no right to expec (excepting in rare cases) to discover DIRECTLY connecting links betwee them, but only between each and some extinct and supplanted form.
As all the modified descendants from a common and widely-diffused species belonging to a large genus, will tend to partake of the same advantage which made their parent successful in life, they will generally go o multiplying in number as well as diverging in character:  this i represented in the diagram by the several divergent branches proceedin from (A).
As all the organic beings, extinct and recent, which have ever lived, ca be arranged within a few great classes; and as all within each class have according to our theory, been connected together by fine gradations, th best, and, if our collections were nearly perfect, the only possibl arrangement, would be genealogical; descent being the hidden bond o connexion which naturalists have been seeking under the term of the Natura System.
As all the species of the same genus are supposed to be descended from  common progenitor, it might be expected that they would occasionally var in an analogous manner; so that the varieties of two or more species woul resemble each other, or that a variety of one species would resemble i certain characters another and distinct species, this other species being according to our view, only a well-marked and permanent variety.
As all these mark are characteristic of the parent rock-pigeon, I presume that no one wil doubt that this is a case of reversion, and not of a new yet analogou variation appearing in the several breeds.
As allied or representative species, when inhabiting a continuous area, ar generally distributed in such a manner that each has a wide range, with  comparatively narrow neutral territory between them, in which they becom rather suddenly rarer and rarer; then, as varieties do not essentiall differ from species, the same rule will probably apply to both; and if w take a varying species inhabiting a very large area, we shall have to adap two varieties to two large areas, and a third variety to a narro intermediate zone.

As in reciprocal crosses, the facility of effecting a union is often very far from equal, so it sometimes is in grafting.

As man can produce, and certainly has produced, a great result by hi methodical and unconscious means of selection, what may not natura selection effect?  Man can act only on external and visible characters: Nature, if I may be allowed to personify the natural preservation o survival of the fittest, cares nothing for appearances, except in so far a they are useful to any being.
As many creatures, besides birds, are affected by the approach of rain of wind, such indications should not be slighted by the observer of weather.
As many more individuals of each species are born than can possibl survive; and as, consequently, there is a frequently recurring struggle fo existence, it follows that any being, if it vary however slightly in an manner profitable to itself, under the complex and sometimes varyin conditions of life, will have a better chance of surviving, and thus b NATURALLY SELECTED. From the strong principle of inheritance, any selecte variety will tend to propagate its new and modified form.
As modifications of corporeal structure arise from, an are increased by, use or habit, and are diminished or lost by disuse, so  do not doubt it has been with instincts.
As natural selection acts by competition, it adapts and improves th inhabitants of each country only in relation to their co-inhabitants; s that we need feel no surprise at the species of any one country, althoug on the ordinary view supposed to have been created and specially adapte for that country, being beaten and supplanted by the naturalise productions from another land.
As natural selection acts by life and death, by the survival of th fittest, and by the destruction of the less well-fitted individuals, I hav sometimes felt great difficulty in understanding the origin or formation o parts of little importance; almost as great, though of a very differen kind, as in the case of the most perfect and complex organs.
As natural selection acts only by the accumulation of slight modification of structure or instinct, each profitable to the individual under it conditions of life, it may reasonably be asked, how a long and graduate succession of modified architectural instincts, all tending towards th present perfect plan of construction, could have profited the progenitor of the hive-bee?  I think the answer is not difficult:  cells constructe like those of the bee or the wasp gain in strength, and save much in labou and space, and in the materials of which they are constructed.
As natural selection acts solely by accumulating slight, successive favourable variations, it can produce no great or sudden modifications; i can act only by short and slow steps.
As natural selection acts solely by the preservation of profitabl modifications, each new form will tend in a fully-stocked country to tak the place of, and finally to exterminate, its own less improved parent-for and other less-favoured forms with which it comes into competition.

As species are produced and exterminated by slowly acting and stil existing causes, and not by miraculous acts of creation; and as the mos important of all causes of organic change is one which is almos independent of altered and perhaps suddenly altered physical conditions namely, the mutual relation of organism to organism - the improvement of on organism entailing the improvement or the extermination of others; i follows, that the amount of organic change in the fossils of consecutiv formations probably serves as a fair measure of the relative, though no actual lapse of time.
As species belonging to distinct classes have often been adapted b successive slight modifications to live under nearly similar circumstance  - to inhabit, for instance, the three elements of land, air and water - w can perhaps understand how it is that a numerical parallelism has sometime been observed between the subgroups of distinct classes.
As species have generally diverged in character during their lon course of descent and modification, we can understand why it is that th more ancient forms, or early progenitors of each group, so often occupy  position in some degree intermediate between existing groups.
As th amount of modification which animals of all kinds undergo partly depends o the lapse of time, and as the islands which are separated from each other or from the mainland, by shallow channels, are more likely to have bee continuously united within a recent period than the islands separated b deeper channels, we can understand how it is that a relation exists betwee the depth of the sea separating two mammalian faunas, and the degree o their affinity, a relation which is quite inexplicable on the theory o independent acts of creation.
As the accumulation of each formation ha often been interrupted, and as long blank intervals have intervened betwee successive formations, we ought not to expect to find, as I attempted t show in the last chapter, in any one or in any two formations, all th intermediate varieties between the species which appeared at th commencement and close of these periods:  but we ought to find afte intervals, very long as measured by years, but only moderately long a measured geologically, closely allied forms, or, as they have been calle by some authors, representative species; and these assuredly we do find.

Bearing in mind that the mutual relation o organism to organism is of the highest importance, we can see why tw areas, having nearly the same physical conditions, should often b inhabited by very different forms of life; for according to the length o time which has elapsed since the colonists entered one of the regions, o both; according to the nature of the communication which allowed certai forms and not others to enter, either in greater or lesser numbers according or not as those which entered happened to come into more or les direct competition with each other and with the aborigines; and accordin as the immigrants were capable of varying more or less rapidly, there woul ensue in the to or more regions, independently of their physica conditions, infinitely diversified conditions of life; there would be a almost endless amount of organic action and reaction, and we should fin some groups of beings greatly, and some only slightly modified; som developed in great force, some existing in scanty numbers - and this we d find in the several great geographical provinces of the world.
Bearing such facts in mind, it may b believed that under certain circumstances individual differences in th curvature or length of the proboscis, etc., too slight to be appreciated b us, might profit a bee or other insect, so that certain individuals woul be able to obtain their food more quickly than others; and thus th communities to which they belonged would flourish and throw off many swarm inheriting the same peculiarities.

Bu as all groups cannot thus go on increasing in size, for the world would no hold them, the more dominant groups beat the less dominant.
Bu as we have no facts to guide us, speculation on the subject is almos useless.
Bu characters exclusively due to analogous variation would probably be of a unimportant nature, for the preservation of all functionally importan characters will have been determined through natural selection, i accordance with the different habits of the species.
Bu disuse and selection will generally act on each creature, when it has com to maturity and has to play its full part in the struggle for existence and will thus have little power on an organ during early life; hence th organ will not be reduced or rendered rudimentary at this early age.

Bu it is a far more important consideration, that during the process o further modification, by which two varieties are supposed to be converte and perfected into two distinct species, the two which exist in large numbers, from inhabiting larger areas, will have a great advantage over th intermediate variety, which exists in smaller numbers in a narrow an intermediate zone.
Bu structures thus indirectly gained, although at first of no advantage to  species, may subsequently have been taken advantage of by its modifie descendants, under new conditions of life and newly acquired habits.

Can it then b thought improbable, seeing that variations useful to man have undoubtedl occurred, that other variations useful in some way to each being in th great and complex battle of life, should occur in the course of man successive generations?  If such do occur, can we doubt (remembering tha many more individuals are born than can possibly survive) that individual having any advantage, however slight, over others, would have the bes chance of surviving and procreating their kind?  On the other hand, we ma feel sure that any variation in the least degree injurious would be rigidl destroyed.

Changed conditions generally induce mere fluctuatin variability, but sometimes they cause direct and definite effects; an these may become strongly marked in the course of time, though we have no sufficient evidence on this head.
Changed conditions of life are of the highest importance in causin variability, both by acting directly on the organisation, and indirectly b affecting the reproductive system.
Changed habits produce an inherited effect as in the period of th flowering of plants when transported from one climate to another.
Changes of instinct may sometimes b facilitated by the same species having different instincts at differen periods of life, or at different seasons of the year, or when placed unde different circumstances, etc.; in which case either the one or the othe instinct might be preserved by natural selection.
Changes of level in the land must also have been highl influential:  a narrow isthmus now separates two marine faunas; submerg it, or let it formerly have been submerged, and the two faunas will no blend together, or may formerly have blended.

Consequentl evidence of their former existence could be found only among fossil remains which are preserved, as we shall attempt to show in a future chapter, in a extremely imperfect and intermittent record.
Consequentl the groups which are now large, and which generally include many dominan species, tend to go on increasing in size.
Consequentl there is no reason to suppose that they have been inherited from a commo progenitor; for had this been the case they would have closely resemble each other in all respects.
Consequently each newly-formed variety would generally be at firs local, as seems to be the common rule with varieties in a state of nature so that similarly modified individuals would soon exist in a small bod together, and would often breed together.
Consequently if it were to undergo  considerable amount of modification during the deposition of any on geological formation, a section would not include all the fine intermediat gradations which must on our theory have existed, but abrupt, thoug perhaps slight, changes of form.
Consequently natural selection would have ha different materials or variations to work on, in order to arrive at th same functional result; and the structures thus acquired would almos necessarily have differed.
Consequently such parts, being already present i considerable numbers, and being highly variable, would naturally afford th materials for adaptation to the most different purposes; yet they woul generally retain, through the force of inheritance, plain traces of thei original or fundamental resemblance.
Consequently there seems at first no limit to the amount o profitable diversification of structure, and therefore no limit to th number of species which might be produced.
Consequently we have here everything favourable for much modification - fo far more modification than with the Alpine productions, left isolated within a much more recent period, on the several mountain ranges and on th arctic lands of Europe and North America.
Consequently, each new variety or species, during the progress of it formation, will generally press hardest on its nearest kindred, and tend t exterminate them.
Consequently, formations rich in fossils and sufficientl thick and extensive to resist subsequent degradation, will have been forme over wide spaces during periods of subsidence, but only where the supply o sediment was sufficient to keep the sea shallow and to embed and preserv the remains before they had time to decay.
Consequently, if the theory be true, it is indisputable that before th lowest Cambrian stratum was deposited long periods elapsed, as long as, o probably far longer than, the whole interval from the Cambrian age to th present day; and that during these vast periods the world swarmed wit living creatures.
Consequently, in the course of many thousand generations, th most distinct varieties of any one species of grass would have the bes chance of succeeding and of increasing in numbers, and thus of supplantin the less distinct varieties; and varieties, when rendered very distinc from each other, take the rank of species.
Consequently, the competition between fresh water productions will hav been less severe than elsewhere; new forms will have been more slowl produced, and old forms more slowly exterminated.
Consequently, whatever part of th structure of the common progenitor, or of its early descendants, becam variable; variations of this part would, it is highly probable, be take advantage of by natural and sexual selection, in order to fit the severa places in the economy of nature, and likewise to fit the two sexes of th same species to each other, or to fit the males to struggle with othe males for the possession of the females.

Considering the several rules now given, which govern the fertility o first crosses and of hybrids, we see that when forms, which must b considered as good and distinct species, are united, their fertilit graduates from zero to perfect fertility, or even to fertility unde certain conditions in excess; that their fertility, besides being eminentl susceptible to favourable and unfavourable conditions, is innatel variable; that it is by no means always the same in degree in the firs cross and in the hybrids produced from this cross; that the fertility o hybrids is not related to the degree in which they resemble in externa appearance either parent; and lastly, that the facility of making a firs cross between any two species is not always governed by their systemati affinity or degree of resemblance to each other.

Dinner over, we sauntered through the ancient rooms, where the pictures and tapestry were still preserved, and nothing was much changed, except that the people whom we met there had an indefinable kind of look of being at home and at ease, which communicated itself to me, so that I felt that the beautiful old place was mine in the best sense of the word; and my pleasure of past days seemed to add itself to that of to-day, and filled my whole soul with content.
Dinner passed heavily.

Domestic instincts are sometimes spoken of as actions which have becom inherited solely from long-continued and compulsory habit, but this is no true.
Domestic instincts, a they may be called, are certainly far less fixed than natural instincts but they have been acted on by far less rigorous selection, and have bee transmitted for an incomparably shorter period, under less fixed condition of life.
Domestic races often have a somewha monstrous character; by which I mean, that, although differing from eac other and from other species of the same genus, in several triflin respects, they often differ in an extreme degree in some one part, bot when compared one with another, and more especially when compared with th species under nature to which they are nearest allied.
Domesticated productions, on th other hand, which, as shown by the mere fact of their domestication, wer not originally highly sensitive to changes in their conditions of life, an which can now generally resist with undiminished fertility repeated change of conditions, might be expected to produce varieties, which would b little liable to have their reproductive powers injuriously affected by th act of crossing with other varieties which had originated in a like manner.
Dominant species belonging to the larger groups within each class tend t give birth to new and dominant forms; so that each large group tends t become still larger, and at the same time more divergent in character.

Edmund had already gone through the service once since his ordination; and upon this being understood, he had a variety of questions from Crawford as to his feelings and success; questions, which being made, though with the vivacity of friendly interest and quick taste, without any touch of that spirit of banter or air of levity which Edmund knew to be most offensive to Fanny, he had true pleasure in satisfying; and when Crawford proceeded to ask his opinion and give his own as to the properest manner in which particular passages in the service should be delivered, shewing it to be a subject on which he had thought before, and thought with judgment, Edmund was still more and more pleased.
Edmund had descended from that moral elevation which he had maintained before, and they were both as much the better as the happier for the descent.

Edmund might, in the common phrase, do the duty of Thornton, that is, he might read prayers and preach, without giving up Mansfield Park: he might ride over every Sunday, to a house nominally inhabited, and go through divine service; he might be the clergyman of Thornton Lacey every seventh day, for three or four hours, if that would content him.
Edmund now believed himself perfectly acquainted with all that Fanny could tell, or could leave to be conjectured of her sentiments, and he was satisfied.

Edmund was at the Parsonage every day, to be indulged with his favourite instrument: one morning secured an invitation for the next; for the lady could not be unwilling to have a listener, and every thing was soon in a fair train.
Edmund was at this time particularly full of cares: his mind being deeply occupied in the consideration of two important events now at hand, which were to fix his fate in life - ordination and matrimony - events of such a serious character as to make the ball, which would be very quickly followed by one of them, appear of less moment in his eyes than in those of any other person in the house.

Edmund watched the progress of her attention, and was amused and gratified by seeing how she gradually slackened in the needlework, which at the beginning seemed to occupy her totally: how it fell from her hand while she sat motionless over it, and at last, how the eyes which had appeared so studiously to avoid him throughout the day were turned and fixed on Crawford - fixed on him for minutes, fixed on him, in short, till the attraction drew Crawford's upon her, and the book was closed, and the charm was broken.
Edmund would be forgiven for being a clergyman, it seemed, under certain conditions of wealth; and this, she suspected, was all the conquest of prejudice which he was so ready to congratulate himself upon.
Edmund's account of Fanny's disposition he could believe to be just; he supposed she had all those feelings, but he must consider it as very unfortunate that she had; for, less willing than his son to trust to the future, he could not help fearing that if such very long allowances of time and habit were necessary for her, she might not have persuaded herself into receiving his addresses properly before the young man's inclination for paying them were over.
Edmund's deep sighs often reached Fanny.
Edmund's feelings were for the other two.
Edmund's first object the next morning was to see his father alone, and give him a fair statement of the whole acting scheme, defending his own share in it as far only as he could then, in a soberer moment, feel his motives to deserve, and acknowledging, with perfect ingenuousness, that his concession had been attended with such partial good as to make his judgment in it very doubtful.

Embryologica resemblances of all kinds can be accounted for, as we shall hereafter see by the progenitors of our existing species having varied after early youth and having transmitted their newly-acquired characters to their offspring at a corresponding age.

Everything supplied an amusement to the high glee of William's mind, and he was full of frolic and joke in the intervals of their higher-toned subjects, all of which ended, if they did not begin, in praise of the Thrush, conjectures how she would be employed, schemes for an action with some superior force, which (supposing the first lieutenant out of the way, and William was not very merciful to the first lieutenant) was to give himself the next step as soon as possible, or speculations upon prize-money, which was to be generously distributed at home, with only the reservation of enough to make the little cottage comfortable, in which he and Fanny were to pass all their middle and later life together.
Everything that a considerate parent ought to feel was advanced for her use; and everything that an affectionate mother must feel in promoting her children's enjoyment was attributed to her nature.
Everything was a friend, or bore her thoughts to a friend; and though there had been sometimes much of suffering to her; though her motives had often been misunderstood, her feelings disregarded, and her comprehension undervalued; though she had known the pains of tyranny, of ridicule, and neglect, yet almost every recurrence of either had led to something consolatory: her aunt Bertram had spoken for her, or Miss Lee had been encouraging, or, what was yet more frequent or more dear, Edmund had been her champion and her friend: he had supported her cause or explained her meaning, he had told her not to cry, or had given her some proof of affection which made her tears delightful; and the whole was now so blended together, so harmonised by distance, that every former affliction had its charm.
Everything was by that time public beyond a hope.
Everything was now in a regular train: theatre, actors, actresses, and dresses, were all getting forward; but though no other great impediments arose, Fanny found, before many days were past, that it was not all uninterrupted enjoyment to the party themselves, and that she had not to witness the continuance of such unanimity and delight as had been almost too much for her at first.

Excepting the moments of peculiar delight, which any marked or unlooked-for instance of Edmund's consideration of her in the last few months had excited, Fanny had never known so much felicity in her life, as in this unchecked, equal, fearless intercourse with the brother and friend who was opening all his heart to her, telling her all his hopes and fears, plans, and solicitudes respecting that long thought of, dearly earned, and justly valued blessing of promotion; who could give her direct and minute information of the father and mother, brothers and sisters, of whom she very seldom heard; who was interested in all the comforts and all the little hardships of her home at Mansfield; ready to think of every member of that home as she directed, or differing only by a less scrupulous opinion, and more noisy abuse of their aunt Norris, and with whom (perhaps the dearest indulgence of the whole) all the evil and good of their earliest years could be gone over again, and every former united pain and pleasure retraced with the fondest recollection.

Fanny believed there was scarcely a second feeling in common between them; and she may be forgiven by older sages for looking on the chance of Miss Crawford's future improvement as nearly desperate, for thinking that if Edmund's influence in this season of love had already done so little in clearing her judgment, and regulating her notions, his worth would be finally wasted on her even in years of matrimony.

Fanny could not wonder that Edmund was at the Parsonage every morning; she would gladly have been there too, might she have gone in uninvited and unnoticed, to hear the harp; neither could she wonder that, when the evening stroll was over, and the two families parted again, he should think it right to attend Mrs. Grant and her sister to their home, while Mr. Crawford was devoted to the ladies of the Park; but she thought it a very bad exchange; and if Edmund were not there to mix the wine and water for her, would rather go without it than not.
Fanny could read, work, and write, but she had been taught nothing more; and as her cousins found her ignorant of many things with which they had been long familiar, they thought her prodigiously stupid, and for the first two or three weeks were continually bringing some fresh report of it into the drawing-room.
Fanny could with difficulty give the smile that was here asked for.
Fanny dared not make any farther opposition; and with renewed but less happy thanks accepted the necklace again, for there was an expression in Miss Crawford's eyes which she could not be satisfied with.
Fanny did not love Miss Crawford; but she felt very much obliged to her for her present kindness; and when, from taking notice of her work, and wishing she could work as well, and begging for the pattern, and supposing Fanny was now preparing for her appearance, as of course she would come out when her cousin was married, Miss Crawford proceeded to inquire if she had heard lately from her brother at sea, and said that she had quite a curiosity to see him, and imagined him a very fine young man, and advised Fanny to get his picture drawn before he went to sea again - she could not help admitting it to be very agreeable flattery, or help listening, and answering with more animation than she had intended.
Fanny did not share her aunt's composure: she thought of the morrow a great deal, for if the three acts were rehearsed, Edmund and Miss Crawford would then be acting together for the first time; the third act would bring a scene between them which interested her most particularly, and which she was longing and dreading to see how they would perform.
Fanny estranged from him, silent and reserved, was an unnatural state of things; a state which he must break through, and which he could easily learn to think she was wanting him to break through.

Fanny felt that she must; and though she had not waited for that sentence to be thinking of Edmund, such a memento made her particularly awake to his idea, and she fancied him sitting in that room again and again, perhaps in the very spot where she sat now, listening with constant delight to the favourite air, played, as it appeared to her, with superior tone and expression; and though pleased with it herself, and glad to like whatever was liked by him, she was more sincerely impatient to go away at the conclusion of it than she had been before; and on this being evident, she was so kindly asked to call again, to take them in her walk whenever she could, to come and hear more of the harp, that she felt it necessary to be done, if no objection arose at home.

Fanny thought she had never known a day of greater agitation, both of pain and pleasure; but happily the pleasure was not of a sort to die with the day; for every day would restore the knowledge of William's advancement, whereas the pain, she hoped, would return no more.
Fanny was affected.
Fanny was again left to her solitude, and with no increase of pleasant feelings, for she was sorry for almost all that she had seen and heard, astonished at Miss Bertram, and angry with Mr. Crawford.

Fanny was ashamed of her own doubts.

Fanny was just recovered enough to feel that she could not regret it; for to her many other sources of uneasiness was added the severe one of shame for the home in which he found her.
Fanny was led off very willingly, though it was impossible for her to feel much gratitude towards her cousin, or distinguish, as he certainly did, between the selfishness of another person and his own.

Fanny was quite shocked.

Fanny was silent; but not from being convinced that there might not be a remedy found for some of these evils.
Fanny was the only one of the party who found anything to dislike; but since the day at Sotherton, she could never see Mr. Crawford with either sister without observation, and seldom without wonder or censure; and had her confidence in her own judgment been equal to her exercise of it in every other respect, had she been sure that she was seeing clearly, and judging candidly, she would probably have made some important communications to her usual confidant.
Fanny was too well aware of it to have anything to say; and they walked on together some fifty yards in mutual silence and abstraction.
Fanny was very anxious to be useful, and not to appear above her home, or in any way disqualified or disinclined, by her foreign education, from contributing her help to its comforts, and therefore set about working for Sam immediately; and by working early and late, with perseverance and great despatch, did so much that the boy was shipped off at last, with more than half his linen ready.
Fanny was very thankful.
Fanny was worth it all; he held her to be worth every effort of patience, every exertion of mind, but he did not think he could have gone on himself with any woman breathing, without something more to warm his courage than his eyes could discern in hers.
Fanny watched him with never-failing solicitude, and sometimes catching his eye, revived an affectionate smile, which comforted her; but the first day's journey passed without her hearing a word from him on the subjects that were weighing him down.
Fanny went to bed with her heart as full as on the first evening of her arrival at the Park.
Fanny went to her every two or three days: it seemed a kind of fascination: she could not be easy without going, and yet it was without loving her, without ever thinking like her, without any sense of obligation for being sought after now when nobody else was to be had; and deriving no higher pleasure from her conversation than occasional amusement, and that often at the expense of her judgment, when it was raised by pleasantry on people or subjects which she wished to be respected.

Fanny's best consolation was in being assured that Edmund had wished for her very much, and that he should certainly have come back for her, had she not been tired already; but this was not quite sufficient to do away with the pain of having been left a whole hour, when he had talked of only a few minutes, nor to banish the sort of curiosity she felt to know what they had been conversing about all that time; and the result of the whole was to her disappointment and depression, as they prepared by general agreement to return to the house.

Finally, I conclude that, although small isolated area have been in some respects highly favourable for the production of ne species, yet that the course of modification will generally have been mor rapid on large areas; and what is more important, that the new form produced on large areas, which already have been victorious over man competitors, will be those that will spread most widely, and will give ris to the greatest number of new varieties and species.

Finally, it may not be a logical deduction, but to my imagination i is far more satisfactory to look at such instincts as the young cucko ejecting its foster-brothers, ants making slaves, the larvae o ichneumonidae feeding within the live bodies of caterpillars, not a specially endowed or created instincts, but as small consequences of on general law leading to the advancement of all organic beings - namely multiply, vary, let the strongest live and the weakest die.
Finally, the several classes of facts which have been considered in thi chapter, seem to me to proclaim so plainly, that the innumerable species genera and families, with which this world is peopled, are all descended each within its own class or group, from common parents, and have all bee modified in the course of descent, that I should without hesitation adop this view, even if it were unsupported by other facts or arguments.
Finally, then, I conclude that the greater variability of specifi characters, or those which distinguish species from species, than o generic characters, or those which are possessed by all the species; tha the frequent extreme variability of any part which is developed in  species in an extraordinary manner in comparison with the same part in it congeners; and the slight degree of variability in a part, howeve extraordinarily it may be developed, if it be common to a whole group o species; that the great variability of secondary sexual characters an their great difference in closely allied species; that secondary sexual an ordinary specific differences are generally displayed in the same parts o the organisation, are all principles closely connected together.
Finally, then, although in many cases it is most difficult even t conjecture by what transitions organs could have arrived at their presen state; yet, considering how small the proportion of living and known form is to the extinct and unknown, I have been astonished how rarely an orga can be named, towards which no transitional grade is known to lead.
Finally, then, although we are as ignorant of th precise cause of the sterility of first crosses and of hybrids as we ar why animals and plants removed from their natural conditions becom sterile, yet the facts given in this chapter do not seem to me opposed t the belief that species aboriginally existed as varieties.
Finally, varieties cannot be distinguished from species - except, first, b the discovery of intermediate linking forms; and, secondly, by a certai indefinite amount of difference between them; for two forms, if differin very little, are generally ranked as varieties, notwithstanding that the cannot be closely connected; but the amount of difference considere necessary to give to any two forms the rank of species cannot be defined.
Finally, we have seen that natural selection, which follows from th struggle for existence, and which almost inevitably leads to extinction an divergence of character in the descendants from any one parent-species explains that great and universal feature in the affinities of all organi beings, namely, their subordination in group under group.
Finally, with respect to the comparative value of the various groups o species, such as orders, suborders, families, subfamilies, and genera, the seem to be, at least at present, almost arbitrary.

For example: Ten spaces on the vernier being made equal to nine on the scale, each vernier space is one tenth less than a scale space; and if the first line or division of the vernier agree exactly with any line of the scale, the next line of the vernier must be one tenth of a tenth (or one hundredth) of an inch from agreement with the next scale division the following vernier line must be two hundredths out, and so on therefore, the number of such differences (from the next tenth on the scale) at which a vernier line agrees with a scale line, when set, is the number of hundredths to be added to the said tenth; (in a common barometer, reading only to hundredths of an inch).

Go back again, then, and while you live you will see all round you people engaged in making others live lives which are not their own, while they themselves care nothing for their own real lives - men who hate life though they fear death.

Groups of species increase i numbers slowly, and endure for unequal periods of time; for the process o modification is necessarily slow, and depends on many comple contingencies.
Groups of species, living during the same period of time, or living withi the same area, are often characterised by trifling features in common, a of sculpture or colour.
Groups of species, that is, genera and families, follow the same genera rules in their appearance and disappearance as do single species, changin more or less quickly, and in a greater or lesser degree.
Grouse, if not destroyed at some period of their lives, woul increase in countless numbers; they are known to suffer largely from bird of prey; and hawks are guided by eyesight to their prey, - so much so tha on parts of the continent persons are warned not to keep white pigeons, a being the most liable to destruction.

He came right down to the river-side, and lingered a little, looking over the low wall to note the moonlit river, near upon high water, go swirling and glittering up to Chiswick Eyot: as for the ugly bridge below, he did not notice it or think of it, except when for a moment (says our friend) it struck him that he missed the row of lights down stream.

He considered her rather as one who had never thought on the subject enough to be in danger; who had been guarded by youth, a youth of mind as lovely as of person; whose modesty had prevented her from understanding his attentions, and who was still overpowered by the suddenness of addresses so wholly unexpected, and the novelty of a situation which her fancy had never taken into account.

He could not but wonder at her refusing to do anything for a niece whom she had been so forward to adopt; but, as she took early care to make him, as well as Lady Bertram, understand that whatever she possessed was designed for their family, he soon grew reconciled to a distinction which, at the same time that it was advantageous and complimentary to them, would enable him better to provide for Fanny himself.

He despised small game and insignificant personalities, whether in the shape of dukes or bagmen, letting them go by like sea-weed; but show him a refined or powerful face, let him hear a plangent or a penetrating voice, fish for him with a living look in some one's eye, a passionate gesture, a meaning and ambiguous smile, and his mind was instantaneously awakened.

He did not scruple to add that her being at home for a while would be a great advantage to everybody.
He did not understand her: he felt that he did not; and therefore applied to Edmund to tell him how she stood affected on the present occasion, and whether she were more or less happy than she had been.
He did not want abilities but he had no curiosity, and no information beyond his profession; he read only the newspaper and the navy-list; he talked only of the dockyard, the harbour, Spithead, and the Motherbank; he swore and he drank, he was dirty and gross.

He had a sister, who was a child too, and his constant companion.

He had all the disposition to persevere that Sir Thomas could wish him.
He had already ate, and declined staying for their meal.
He had always something to entreat the explanation of.
He had an extraordinary detailed knowledge of the ancient history of the country-side from the time of Alfred to the days of the Parliamentary Wars, many events of which, as you may know, were enacted round about Wallingford.
He had awakened with a certain blank and childish sense of pleasure, like a man who had received a legacy overnight; but this feeling gradually died away, and was then suddenly and stunningly succeeded by a conviction of the truth.
He had been apt to gain hearts too easily.
He had been considering her as a particularly welcome addition at the Parsonage, as a desirable companion to an aunt who had no children of her own; but he found himself wholly mistaken.
He had been in the Mediterranean; in the West Indies; in the Mediterranean again; had been often taken on shore by the favour of his captain, and in the course of seven years had known every variety of danger which sea and war together could offer.
He had been invited to see her.
He had been much in London, and had more liveliness and gallantry than Edmund, and must, therefore, be preferred; and, indeed, his being the eldest was another strong claim.
He had been quite familiar with one old ghost, in a white waistcoat, with a monstrous iron safe attached to its ankle, who cried piteously at being unable to assist a wretched woman with an infant, whom it saw below, upon a door-step.
He had been sobbing violently in his conflict with the Spirit, and his face was wet with tears.
He had been speaking of her cheerfully from the hour of his coming home.
He had been trying to get Dick towards the door, but the latter stood off.
He had been visiting a friend in the neighbouring county, and that friend having recently had his grounds laid out by an improver, Mr. Rushworth was returned with his head full of the subject, and very eager to be improving his own place in the same way; and though not saying much to the purpose, could talk of nothing else.
He had been waiting in the porch for some time back, and Esther had been listlessly standing by his side.
He had begun at the wrong end.
He had but one opinion.
He had come, intending to spend only a few days with them; but Mansfield promised well, and there was nothing to call him elsewhere.
He had concluded - he had meant them to be far distant.
He had dined at the Parsonage only the preceding day.
He had every well-grounded reason for solid attachment; he knew her to have all the worth that could justify the warmest hopes of lasting happiness with her; her conduct at this very time, by speaking the disinterestedness and delicacy of her character (qualities which he believed most rare indeed), was of a sort to heighten all his wishes, and confirm all his resolutions.
He had expected a very different son-in-law; and beginning to feel grave on Maria's account, tried to understand her feelings.
He had felt her as an hourly evil, which was so much the worse, as there seemed no chance of its ceasing but with life; she seemed a part of himself that must be borne for ever.
He had gone, had done even more good than he had foreseen, had been useful to more than his first plan had comprehended, and was now able to congratulate himself upon it, and to feel that in performing a duty, he had secured agreeable recollections for his own mind.
He had had enough of novelties for one day.
He had intended, about this time, to be going to London; but he could not leave his father and mother just when everybody else of most importance to their comfort was leaving them; and with an effort, felt but not boasted of, he delayed for a week or two longer a journey which he was looking forward to with the hope of its fixing his happiness for ever.
He had introduced himself to some tenants whom he had never seen before; he had begun making acquaintance with cottages whose very existence, though on his own estate, had been hitherto unknown to him.
He had just enough recollection of the face to desire to do that.
He had known many disagreeable fathers before, and often been struck with the inconveniences they occasioned, but never, in the whole course of his life, had he seen one of that class so unintelligibly moral, so infamously tyrannical as Sir Thomas.
He had learned his part - all his parts, for he took every trifling one that could be united with the Butler, and began to be impatient to be acting; and every day thus unemployed was tending to increase his sense of the insignificance of all his parts together, and make him more ready to regret that some other play had not been chosen.
He had lost his love - he had lost his love for good.
He had lost his love, he thought - he had lost his love for good.
He had made a point always of standing well in their esteem: in a business point of view, that is; strictly in a business point of view.
He had meant them to be good, but his cares had been directed to the understanding and manners, not the disposition; and of the necessity of self-denial and humility, he feared they had never heard from any lips that could profit them.
He had never been so kind, so very kind to her in his life.
He had never dreamed that any walk - that anything - could give him so much happiness.
He had never knowingly given her pain, but he now felt that she required more positive kindness; and with that view endeavoured, in the first place, to lessen her fears of them all, and gave her especially a great deal of good advice as to playing with Maria and Julia, and being as merry as possible.
He had no clue to her reflections; but he could not conceal from his own heart that he must have sunk in her esteem, and the spectacle of her infatuation galled him like an insult.
He had no further intercourse with Spirits, but lived upon the Total Abstinence Principle, ever afterwards; and it was always said of him, that he knew how to keep Christmas well, if any man alive possessed the knowledge.
He had no idea of concealment.
He had not given her time to attach herself.
He had not to wait and wish with vacant affections for an object worthy to succeed her in them.
He had often seen it tried.
He had previously made her the happiest of human beings, and now he had insulted - she knew not what to say, how to class, or how to regard it.
He had put out his hand to bar her entrance, and she had submitted without surprise; and though she seemed to listen, she scarcely appeared to comprehend.
He had reached it late the night before, was come for a day or two, was staying at the Crown, had accidentally met with a navy officer or two of his acquaintance since his arrival, but had no object of that kind in coming.
He had received a note from Lady Stornaway to beg him to call; and regarding it as what was meant to be the last, last interview of friendship, and investing her with all the feelings of shame and wretchedness which Crawford's sister ought to have known, he had gone to her in such a state of mind, so softened, so devoted, as made it for a few moments impossible to Fanny's fears that it should be the last.
He had said enough to shake the experience of eighteen.
He had seen Miss Crawford.
He had since heard her express herself differently, with other feelings, more chequered feelings: he had heard her tell Mrs. Grant that she should leave her with regret; that she began to believe neither the friends nor the pleasures she was going to were worth those she left behind; and that though she felt she must go, and knew she should enjoy herself when once away, she was already looking forward to being at Mansfield again.
He had spent more money - no less than three individual fortunes, it was whispered - than any of his associates could ever hope to gain.
He had suffered, and he had learned to think: two advantages that he had never known before; and the self-reproach arising from the deplorable event in Wimpole Street, to which he felt himself accessory by all the dangerous intimacy of his unjustifiable theatre, made an impression on his mind which, at the age of six-and-twenty, with no want of sense or good companions, was durable in its happy effects.
He had suspected his agent of some underhand dealing; of meaning to bias him against the deserving; and he had determined to go himself, and thoroughly investigate the merits of the case.
He had the best right to be the talker; and the delight of his sensations in being again in his own house, in the centre of his family, after such a separation, made him communicative and chatty in a very unusual degree; and he was ready to give every information as to his voyage, and answer every question of his two sons almost before it was put.
He had the offer of Count Cassel and Anhalt, and at first did not know which to chuse, and wanted Miss Bertram to direct him; but upon being made to understand the different style of the characters, and which was which, and recollecting that he had once seen the play in London, and had thought Anhalt a very stupid fellow, he soon decided for the Count.
He had three horses of his own, but not one that would carry a woman.
He had to reinstate himself in all the wonted concerns of his Mansfield life: to see his steward and his bailiff; to examine and compute, and, in the intervals of business, to walk into his stables and his gardens, and nearest plantations; but active and methodical, he had not only done all this before he resumed his seat as master of the house at dinner, he had also set the carpenter to work in pulling down what had been so lately put up in the billiard-room, and given the scene-painter his dismissal long enough to justify the pleasing belief of his being then at least as far off as Northampton.
He had told her the most extraordinary, the most inconceivable, the most unwelcome news; and she could think of nothing else.
He had vanity, which strongly inclined him in the first place to think she did love him, though she might not know it herself; and which, secondly, when constrained at last to admit that she did know her own present feelings, convinced him that he should be able in time to make those feelings what he wished.
He hardly knew whether there were any difference in her spirits or not.
He has a fine dignified manner, which suits the head of such a house, and keeps everybody in their place.

He showed us, among other things, an account of a certain village council who were working hard at all this business; and the record of their intense earnestness in getting to the bottom of some matter which in time past would have been thought quite trivial, as, for example, the due proportions of alkali and oil for soap-making for the village wash, or the exact heat of the water into which a leg of mutton should be plunged for boiling - all this joined to the utter absence of anything like party feeling, which even in a village assembly would certainly have made its appearance in an earlier epoch, was very amusing, and at the same time instructive.

He turned it gently, and sidled his face in, round the door.
He ventured to raise his eyes again, and found his supernatural visitor confronting him in an erect attitude, with its chain wound over and about its arm.
He walked with fatigue, he leaned upon the staff; he looked round him with a sad, smiling sympathy on all that he beheld; he even asked the name of a plant, and rallied himself gently for an old town bird, ignorant of nature.
He was a handsome young fellow, with a peculiarly pleasant and friendly look about his eyes, - an expression which was quite new to me then, though I soon became familiar with it.
He was a heavy young man, with not more than common sense; but as there was nothing disagreeable in his figure or address, the young lady was well pleased with her conquest.
He was a man in the prime of life, but looked as happy as a child who has just got a new toy.
He was a type-hunter among mankind.
He was a whist player himself, and perhaps might feel that it would not much amuse him to have her for a partner.
He was about to speak; but with her head turned from him, she resumed.
He was after her immediately.
He was anxious, while vindicating himself, to say nothing unkind of the others: but there was only one amongst them whose conduct he could mention without some necessity of defence or palliation.
He was ashamed to think that for four days together she had not had the power of riding, and very seriously resolved, however unwilling he must be to check a pleasure of Miss Crawford's, that it should never happen again.
He was at home in five minutes.
He was aware of what Edmund must be suffering on his own behalf, in addition to all the rest, when they were in town: he had seen or conjectured his feelings; and, having reason to think that one interview with Miss Crawford had taken place, from which Edmund derived only increased distress, had been as anxious on that account as on others to get him out of town, and had engaged him in taking Fanny home to her aunt, with a view to his relief and benefit, no less than theirs.
He was aware that he must not expect a genius in Mr. Rushworth; but as a well-judging, steady young man, with better notions than his elocution would do justice to, he intended to value him very highly.
He was certainly better pleased to hand her into the barouche than to assist her in ascending the box, and his complacency seemed confirmed by the arrangement.
He was conscious of being exhausted, and overcome by an irresistible drowsiness; and, further, of being in his own bedroom.
He was decidedly improved.
He was deep in thought.
He was delighted with him.
He was determined to prevent it, if possible, though his mother, who equally heard the conversation which passed at table, did not evince the least disapprobation.
He was doing all in his power to quiet everything, with the hope of Mrs. Rushworth's return, but was so much counteracted in Wimpole Street by the influence of Mr. Rushworth's mother, that the worst consequences might be apprehended.
He was dressed in a sort of Norfolk jacket of blue serge worn threadbare, with breeches of the same, and grey worsted stockings.
He was endeavouring to pierce the darkness with his ferret eyes, when the chimes of a neighbouring church struck the four quarters.
He was engaged to dinner already both for that day and the next; he had met with some acquaintance at the Crown who would not be denied; he should have the honour, however, of waiting on them again on the morrow, etc., and so they parted - Fanny in a state of actual felicity from escaping so horrible an evil To have had him join their family dinner-party, and see all their deficiencies, would have been dreadful! Rebecca's cookery and Rebecca's waiting, and Betsey's eating at table without restraint, and pulling everything about as she chose, were what Fanny herself was not yet enough inured to for her often to make a tolerable meal.
He was entangled by his own vanity, with as little excuse of love as possible, and without the smallest inconstancy of mind towards her cousin.
He was evidently oppressed, and Fanny must grieve for him, though hoping she might never see him again till he were the husband of some other woman.
He was full eighteen minutes and a half behind his time.
He was gone - he had touched her hand for the last time, he had made his parting bow, and she might seek directly all that solitude could do for her.
He was gone again; glad to get away even from Fanny.
He was gone as he spoke; and Fanny remained to tranquillise herself as she could.
He was gone before anything had been said to prepare him for the change he must find there; and a pause of alarm followed his disappearance.
He was in distress for something that he had left there, and did not find again.
He was in high spirits, doing everything with happy ease, and preeminent in all the lively turns, quick resources, and playful impudence that could do honour to the game; and the round table was altogether a very comfortable contrast to the steady sobriety and orderly silence of the other.
He was in love, very much in love; and it was a love which, operating on an active, sanguine spirit, of more warmth than delicacy, made her affection appear of greater consequence because it was withheld, and determined him to have the glory, as well as the felicity, of forcing her to love him.
He was just entering into life, full of spirits, and with all the liberal dispositions of an eldest son, who feels born only for expense and enjoyment.
He was no longer in doubt of the capabilities of her heart.
He was not a man to be endured but for his children's sake, and he might be thankful to his fair daughter Julia that Mr. Yates did yet mean to stay a few days longer under his roof.
He was not alone, but sat by the side of a fair young girl in a mourning-dress: in whose eyes there were tears, which sparkled in the light that shone out of the Ghost of Christmas Past.
He was not intending, however, by such action, to be conveying to her that unqualified approbation and encouragement which her hopes drew from it.
He was not near, he was attending a party of ladies out of the room; and Mrs. Grant coming up to the two girls, and taking an arm of each, they followed with the rest.
He was not one of those tough-hided and small-hearted males who would marry their love at the point of the bayonet rather than not marry her at all.
He was not only very ill, but dying, then.
He was not reading now, but walking up and down despairingly.
He was not so well-looking or so strongly made as my sculler friend, being sandy-haired, rather pale, and not stout-built; but his face was not wanting in that happy and friendly expression which I had noticed in his friend.
He was not very solid; but there was a hope of his becoming less trifling, of his being at least tolerably domestic and quiet; and at any rate, there was comfort in finding his estate rather more, and his debts much less, than he had feared, and in being consulted and treated as the friend best worth attending to.
He was now the Mr. Crawford who was addressing herself with ardent, disinterested love; whose feelings were apparently become all that was honourable and upright, whose views of happiness were all fixed on a marriage of attachment; who was pouring out his sense of her merits, describing and describing again his affection, proving as far as words could prove it, and in the language, tone, and spirit of a man of talent too, that he sought her for her gentleness and her goodness; and to complete the whole, he was now the Mr. Crawford who had procured William's promotion Here was a change, and here were claims which could not but operate! She might have disdained him in all the dignity of angry virtue, in the grounds of Sotherton, or the theatre at Mansfield Park; but he approached her now with rights that demanded different treatment.
He was obliged to rub the frost off with the sleeve of his dressing-gown before he could see anything; and could see very little then.
He was obliged to sit close to it, and brood over it, before he could extract the least sensation of warmth from such a handful of fuel.
He was older now; a man in the prime of life.
He was on his stool in a jiffy; driving away with his pen, as if he were trying to overtake nine o'clock.
He was only too good to everybody.
He was posting away as if upon life and death, and could but just spare time to tell us his errand, and where you all were.
He was reconciled to what had happened, and went down again quite happy.
He was released from the engagement to be mortified and unhappy, till some other pretty girl could attract him into matrimony again, and he might set forward on a second, and, it is to be hoped, more prosperous trial of the state: if duped, to be duped at least with good humour and good luck; while she must withdraw with infinitely stronger feelings to a retirement and reproach which could allow no second spring of hope or character.
He was returning to Mansfield with spirits ready to feed on melancholy remembrances, and tender associations, when her own fair self was before him, leaning on her brother's arm, and he found himself receiving a welcome, unquestionably friendly, from the woman whom, two moments before, he had been thinking of as seventy miles off, and as farther, much farther, from him in inclination than any distance could express.
He was right, he was a broken man.
He was roused from the reverie of retrospection and regret produced by it, by some inquiry from Edmund as to his plans for the next day's hunting; and he found it was as well to be a man of fortune at once with horses and grooms at his command.
He was silent for some time, and I would not interrupt him.
He was still ailing, it was said, and the squire nursed him like the proverbial woman.
He was suffering from disappointment and regret, grieving over what was, and wishing for what could never be.
He was the better for ever for his illness.
He was to be a clergyman.
He was to go to town as soon as some business relative to Thornton Lacey were completed -  perhaps within a fortnight; he talked of going, he loved to talk of it; and when once with her again, Fanny could not doubt the rest.
He was very much attached to me, was Dick.
He was very willing to hope that Crawford saw clearer, and this was the most comfortable conclusion for his friend that he could come to from all that he observed to pass before, and at, and after dinner.
He was well looked after; for a little lad of about seven years old had his hand on the rein and was solemnly looking up into his face; on his back, withal, was a girl of fourteen, holding a three-year old sister on before her; while another girl, about a year older than the boy, hung on behind.
He was, in fact, entirely on his father's side of the question.
He was, in fact, the most agreeable young man the sisters had ever known, and they were equally delighted with him.
He was, perhaps, but at treacherous play with her.
He watched her with this idea; but he could hardly tell with what success.
He went for a fortnight - a fortnight of such dullness to the Miss Bertrams as ought to have put them both on their guard, and made even Julia admit, in her jealousy of her sister, the absolute necessity of distrusting his attentions, and wishing him not to return; and a fortnight of sufficient leisure, in the intervals of shooting and sleeping, to have convinced the gentleman that he ought to keep longer away, had he been more in the habit of examining his own motives, and of reflecting to what the indulgence of his idle vanity was tending; but, thoughtless and selfish from prosperity and bad example, he would not look beyond the present moment.
He went further, and declared that whatever his opinion might be as to the doctrines of the Socialists, he for one should throw in his lot with the people, until the Government atoned for their atrocity by showing that they were prepared to listen to the demands of men who knew what they wanted, and whom the decrepitude of society forced into pushing their demands in some way or other.
He went the whole length of the expression, and said that he would see him in that extremity first.
He went to while away the next three hours as he could, with his other acquaintance, till the best dinner that a capital inn afforded was ready for their enjoyment, and she turned in to her more simple one immediately.
He went; but there was no reading, no China, no composure for Fanny.
He wh rejects it, rejects the vera causa of ordinary generation with subsequen migration, and calls in the agency of a miracle.
He who admit the doctrine of the creation of each separate species, will have to admi that a sufficient number of the best adapted plants and animals were no created for oceanic islands; for man has unintentionally stocked them fa more fully and perfectly than did nature.
He who believes in separate and innumerable acts of creation may say, tha in these cases it has pleased the Creator to cause a being of one type t take the place of one belonging to another type; but this seems to me onl restating the fact in dignified language.
He who believes in the struggl for existence and in the principle of natural selection, will acknowledg that every organic being is constantly endeavouring to increase in numbers and that if any one being varies ever so little, either in habits o structure, and thus gains an advantage over some other inhabitant of th same country, it will seize on the place of that inhabitant, howeve different that may be from its own place.
He who believes that each being has been created as we now see it, mus occasionally have felt surprise when he has met with an animal havin habits and structure not in agreement.
He who believes that each equine species was independently created, will,  presume, assert that each species has been created with a tendency to vary both under nature and under domestication, in this particular manner, so a often to become striped like the other species of the genus; and that eac has been created with a strong tendency, when crossed with specie inhabiting distant quarters of the world, to produce hybrids resembling i their stripes, not their own parents, but other species of the genus.
He who believes that some ancient form was transformed suddenly through a internal force or tendency into, for instance, one furnished with wings will be almost compelled to assume, in opposition to all analogy, that man individuals varied simultaneously.
He who can read Sir Charles Lyell's grand work on the Principles o Geology, which the future historian will recognise as having produced  revolution in natural science, and yet does not admit how vast have bee the past periods of time, may at once close this volume.
He who i acquainted with the distribution of existing species over the globe, wil not attempt to account for the close resemblance of distinct species i closely consecutive formations, by the physical conditions of the ancien areas having remained nearly the same.
He who is able t explain why the elephant, and a multitude of other animals, are incapabl of breeding when kept under only partial confinement in their nativ country, will be able to explain the primary cause of hybrids being s generally sterile.
He who rejects this view of the imperfection of the geological record, wil rightly reject the whole theory.
He who wil carefully examine the flowers of orchids for himself will not deny th existence of the above series of gradations - from a mass of pollen-grain merely tied together by threads, with the stigma differing but little fro that of the ordinary flowers, to a highly complex pollinium, admirabl adapted for transportal by insects; nor will he deny that all th gradations in the several species are admirably adapted in relation to th general structure of each flower for its fertilisation by differen insects.
He who wil explain in a definite manner why, for instance, an elephant or a fox wil not breed under confinement in its native country, whilst the domestic pi or dog will breed freely under the most diversified conditions, will at th same time be able to give a definite answer to the question why tw distinct species, when crossed, as well as their hybrid offspring, ar generally rendered more or less sterile, while two domesticated varietie when crossed and their mongrel offspring are perfectly fertile.
He who will explain these latter cases will be able t explain the sterility of hybrids.
He who will go thus far, ought not to hesitate to go one step further, i he finds on finishing this volume that large bodies of facts, otherwis inexplicable, can be explained by the theory of modification throug natural selection; he ought to admit that a structure even as perfect as a eagle's eye might thus be formed, although in this case he does not kno the transitional states.
He who will read my memoir on these plants will, I think, admi that all the many gradations in function and structure between simpl twiners and tendril-bearers are in each case beneficial in a high degree t the species.
He will at the same time be able to explain how it i that the races of some of our domesticated animals, which have often bee subjected to new and not uniform conditions, are quite fertile together although they are descended from distinct species, which would probabl have been sterile if aboriginally crossed.
He will be forced to admit that thes great and sudden transformations have left no trace of their action on th embryo.
He will be no bad assistant when it all comes out.
He will be taken in at last.
He will further be compelled to believ that many structures beautifully adapted to all the other parts of the sam creature and to the surrounding conditions, have been suddenly produced and of such complex and wonderful co-adaptations, he will not be able t assign a shadow of an explanation.
He will have a very pretty income to make ducks and drakes with, and earned without much trouble.
He will make you happy, Fanny; I know he will make you happy; but you will make him everything.
He will marry her, and be poor and miserable.
He will not do by the side of your cousin Edmund.
He will satisfy you.
He will see the Rushworths, which own I am not sorry for - having a little curiosity, and so I think has he - though he will not acknowledge it.
He wished him to be a model of constancy; and fancied the best means of effecting it would be by not trying him too long.
He wondered that Fanny spoke so seldom of her, and had so little voluntarily to say of her concern at this separation.
He would act for her and release her.
He would be at home in September, and where would be the harm of only waiting till September Though Edmund was much more displeased with his aunt than with his mother, as evincing least regard for her niece, he could not help paying more attention to what she said; and at length determined on a method of proceeding which would obviate the risk of his father's thinking he had done too much, and at the same time procure for Fanny the immediate means of exercise, which he could not bear she should be without.
He would enjoy her liveliness and she has talents to value his powers.
He would find that they yielded only about one-fifth of th proper number of seed, and that they behaved in all the other abov specified respects as if they had been two distinct species.
He would have me go ashore, as if to show me something which I had never seen before; and nothing loth I followed him, Ellen by my side, to the well-remembered Dykes, and the long church beyond them, which was still used for various purposes by the good folk of Dorchester: where, by the way, the village guest-house still had the sign of the Fleur-de-luce which it used to bear in the days when hospitality had to be bought and sold.
He would have preferred her to await him in the road while he went on and brought the carriage back, but after so many repulses and rebuffs he lacked courage to offer the suggestion.
He would have sent you a description of everything and everybody.
He would have snapped 'em short off in a minute, like sticks of sealing-wax.
He would have taken no pains to be on terms with Mrs. Rushworth again.
He would marry Miss Crawford.
He would not despair: he would not desist.
He would see you were his own son after all, and had the same thoughts and the same chivalry of spirit.
He would soon be always gone; and she was thankful that she could now sit in the same room with her uncle, hear his voice, receive his questions, and even answer them, without such wretched feelings as she had formerly known.
He would walk round the ramparts, and join them with the carriage.
He wrote in April, and had strong hopes of settling everything to his entire satisfaction, and leaving Antigua before the end of the summer.
He wrote with his own hand his love to his cousin William, and sent him half a guinea under the seal.
He yielded, but it was with agonies which did not admit of speech.
He, complete in his lieutenant's uniform, looking and moving all the taller, firmer, and more graceful for it, and with the happiest smile over his face, walked up directly to Fanny, who, rising from her seat, looked at him for a moment in speechless admiration, and then threw her arms round his neck to sob out her various emotions of pain and pleasure.
He, indeed, I have lately thought, has seen the woman he could love, which, I am convinced, my eldest son has not.
He, on his part, was full of airs and graces and geniality.
He, who had married a daughter to Mr. Rushworth: romantic delicacy was certainly not to be expected from him.
Heaped up on the floor, to form a kind of throne, were turkeys, geese, game, poultry, brawn, great joints of meat, sucking-pigs, long wreaths of sausages, mince-pies, plum-puddings, barrels of oysters, red-hot chestnuts, cherry-cheeked apples, juicy oranges, luscious pears, immense twelfth-cakes, and seething bowls of punch, that made the chamber dim with their delicious steam.

Henc number is of the highest importance for success.

Hence adaptation t any special climate may be looked at as a quality readily grafted on a innate wide flexibility of constitution, common to most animals.
Hence all the intermediate forms between the earlier an later states, that is between the less and more improved states of a th same species, as well as the original parent-species itself, will generall tend to become extinct.
Hence an oceanic island at first sight seems to have been highly favourabl for the production of new species.
Hence during a long-continued course of modification, th slight differences characteristic of varieties of the same species, tend t be augmented into the greater differences characteristic of the species o the same genus.
Hence i the several fishes furnished with electric organs, these cannot b considered as homologous, but only as analogous in function.
Hence if man goes on selecting, and thus augmenting, any peculiarity, h will almost certainly modify unintentionally other parts of the structure owing to the mysterious laws of correlation.
Hence it has been argued that no deductions can be drawn fro domestic races to species in a state of nature.
Hence it is by no means surprising that one specie should retain the same identical form much longer than others; or, i changing, should change in a less degree.
Hence it is evident, that before horizontal motion occurs, an augmentation or diminution of pressure must take place somewhere more or less remote and so it is with the lighter fluid atmosphere, which has centres lines, or areas of depression towards which currents flow.
Hence it is not a little difficult t decide how far even the same terms ought to be employed in describing th eyes of the Cephalopoda and Vertebrata.
Hence it is tha existing species during the early stages of their development so ofte resemble ancient and extinct forms belonging to the same class.
Hence it is the most flourishing, or, as they may b called, the dominant species - those which range widely, are the mos diffused in their own country, and are the most numerous i individuals - which oftenest produce well-marked varieties, or, as  consider them, incipient species.
Hence it might have been expected that in th few species belonging to both families which live on the land, the equall important air-breathing apparatus would have been the same; for why shoul this one apparatus, given for the same purpose, have been made to differ while all the other important organs were closely similar, or rather identical.
Hence it must b assumed, not only that half-civilized man succeeded in thoroughl domesticating several species, but that he intentionally or by chanc picked out extraordinarily abnormal species; and further, that these ver species have since all become extinct or unknown.
Hence it seems that, on the one hand, slight changes in the conditions o life benefit all organic beings, and on the other hand, that sligh crosses, that is, crosses between the males and females of the sam species, which have been subjected to slightly different conditions, o which have slightly varied, give vigour and fertility to the offspring.
Hence it will cause him n surprise that there should be geese and frigate-birds with webbed feet living on the dry land and rarely alighting on the water, that there shoul be long-toed corncrakes, living in meadows instead of in swamps; that ther should be woodpeckers where hardly a tree grows; that there should b diving thrushes and diving Hymenoptera, and petrels with the habits o auks.

Hence the barometer shows, and generally foretells, changes of wind; but as complications always occur, and as changes are of greater or les extent, affecting or extending through a wider or more limited area accompanied by hygrometric and electrical alterations, it is extremely difficult at times to say beforehand what particular change of weather is to be expected, and at what interval of time; although after the event the correspondence of barometric changes with those of the weather can be readily traced.
