Hence very few of the original species will hav transmitted offspring to the fourteen-thousandth generation.
Hence w may confidently assert that all plants and animals are tending to increas at a geometrical ratio - that all would rapidly stock every station in whic they could any how exist, and that this geometrical tendency to increas must be checked by destruction at some period of life.
Hence we can see that when a plant or animal is placed in a new country among new competitors, the conditions of its life will generally be change in an essential manner, although the climate may be exactly the same as i its former home.
Hence we can understand, bearing in mind that eac organic being is trying to live wherever it can live, how it has arise that there are upland geese with webbed feet, ground woodpeckers, divin thrushes, and petrels with the habits of auks.
Hence we may infe as highly probable that, if the whole genus of humble-bees became extinc or very rare in England, the heartsease and red clover would become ver rare, or wholly disappear.
Hence we may safel infer that icebergs formerly landed their rocky burdens on the shores o these mid-ocean islands, and it is at least possible that they may hav brought thither the seeds of northern plants.
Hence we may safely conclude that, if we could slightly modify th instincts already possessed by the Melipona, and in themselves not ver wonderful, this bee would make a structure as wonderfully perfect as tha of the hive-bee.
Hence we ought not to expect at the present time to meet with numerou transitional varieties in each region, though they must have existed there and may be embedded there in a fossil condition.
Hence when in former times an immigrant first settled on one of the islands, o when it subsequently spread from one to another, it would undoubtedly b exposed to different conditions in the different islands, for it would hav to compete with a different set of organisms; a plant, for instance, woul find the ground best-fitted for it occupied by somewhat different specie in the different islands, and would be exposed to the attacks of somewha different enemies.
Hence when we find that hybrids produced by a cross betwee two distinct species are few in number, owing to their perishing soon afte conception or at a very early age, or if surviving that they are rendere more or less sterile, it seems highly probable that this result is due t their having been in fact subjected to a great change in their condition of life, from being compounded of two distinct organisations.
Hence with animals of this nature, fo instance birds, varieties will generally be confined to separate countries; and this I find to be the case.
Hence, I can see no great difficulty in any characte becoming correlated with the sterile condition of certain members of insec communities; the difficulty lies in understanding how such correlate modifications of structure could have been slowly accumulated by natura selection.
Hence, I was led to predict that some slight tendenc to a movement of this kind would be found to be far from uncommon wit plants which did not climb; and that this had afforded the basis fo natural selection to work on and improve.
Hence, I will give the observation which I made in some little detail.
Hence, after long intervals of time, the productions of th world appear to have changed simultaneously.
Hence, also, it has been found that  classification founded on any single character, however important that ma be, has always failed; for no part of the organisation is invariabl constant.
Hence, although under nature i must generally be left doubtful, what cases are reversions to formerl existing characters, and what are new but analogous variations, yet w ought, on our theory, sometimes to find the varying offspring of a specie assuming characters which are already present in other members of the sam group.
Hence, as has often been remarked, a species ma depart from its allies in several characters, both of high physiologica importance, and of almost universal prevalence, and yet leave us in n doubt where it should be ranked.
Hence, as in the case of corporeal structures, w ought to find in nature, not the actual transitional gradations by whic each complex instinct has been acquired - for these could be found only i the lineal ancestors of each species - but we ought to find in th collateral lines of descent some evidence of such gradations; or we ough at least to be able to show that gradations of some kind are possible; an this we certainly can do.
Hence, as more individuals are produced than can possibl survive, there must in every case be a struggle for existence, either on individual with another of the same species, or with the individuals o distinct species, or with the physical conditions of life.
Hence, as the intelligent reader can foresee, this groom has a part to play in the imbroglio.

Hence, i certain insectivorous birds were to decrease in Paraguay, the parasiti insects would probably increase; and this would lessen the number of th navel-frequenting flies - then cattle and horses would become feral, an this would certainly greatly alter (as indeed I have observed in parts o South America) the vegetation:  this again would largely affect th insects; and this, as we have just seen in Staffordshire, the insectivorou birds, and so onwards in ever-increasing circles of complexity.
Hence, i is clear that the slaves feel quite at home.
Hence, if any one specie of grass were to go on varying, and the varieties were continually selecte which differed from each other in the same manner, though in a very sligh degree, as do the distinct species and genera of grasses, a greater numbe of individual plants of this species, including its modified descendants would succeed in living on the same piece of ground.
Hence, if we look a each species as descended from some unknown form, both the parent and al the transitional varieties will generally have been exterminated by th very process of the formation and perfection of the new form.
Hence, in accordance with the principles inculcate in this volume, these forms will not have been liable to much modification.
Hence, in all such cases, we should b unable to recognise the parent-form of any two or more species, even if w closely compared the structure of the parent with that of its modifie descendants, unless at the same time we had a nearly perfect chain of th intermediate links.
Hence, in determining whether a form should be ranked as a species or  variety, the opinion of naturalists having sound judgment and wid experience seems the only guide to follow.
Hence, in fact, the la of the Conditions of Existence is the higher law; as it includes, throug the inheritance of former variations and adaptations, that of Unity o Type.
Hence, in order that a new species should suddenl appear in the manner supposed by Mr. Mivart, it is almost necessary t believe, in opposition to all analogy, that several wonderfully change individuals appeared simultaneously within the same district.
Hence, it has come, that when w compare the now living productions of the temperate regions of the New an Old Worlds, we find very few identical species (though Asa Gray has latel shown that more plants are identical than was formerly supposed), but w find in every great class many forms, which some naturalists rank a geographical races, and others as distinct species; and a host of closel allied or representative forms which are ranked by all naturalists a specifically distinct.
Hence, it is probable that in some parts of the world whol formations have been completely denuded, with not a wreck left behind.
Hence, it will perhaps be safest to look at the entire absenc of the anterior tarsi in Ateuchus, and their rudimentary condition in som other genera, not as cases of inherited mutilations, but as due to th effects of long-continued disuse; for as many dung-feeding beetles ar generally found with their tarsi lost, this must happen early in life therefore the tarsi cannot be of much importance or be much used by thes insects.
Hence, it woul continually be more and more advantageous to our humble-bees, if they wer to make their cells more and more regular, nearer together, and aggregate into a mass, like the cells of the Melipona; for in this case a large par of the bounding surface of each cell would serve to bound the adjoinin cells, and much labour and wax would be saved.
Hence, rare species will b less quickly modified or improved within any given period; they wil consequently be beaten in the race for life by the modified and improve descendants of the commoner species.
Hence, supposing the three causes to act together - in extreme cases - the mercury might range from about 31 inches to near 27 inches, which has happened occasionally.
Hence, the more common forms, in the rac for life, will tend to beat and supplant the less common forms, for thes will be more slowly modified and improved.
Hence, the structure of each part of each species, fo whatever purpose it may serve, is the sum of many inherited changes through which the species has passed during its successive adaptations t changed habits and conditions of life.
Hence, the struggle for the productio of new and modified descendants will mainly lie between the larger groups which are all trying to increase in number.
Hence, too, it came about that Dick Naseby, a high-minded creature, and as scrupulous and brave a gentleman as you would want to meet, held in a sort of affection the various human creeping things whom he had met and studied.
Hence, we can understan how it is that these organs graduate in some cases, as I am informed by Mr. Busk, into each other.
Hence, we can understand how it is that the flora o Madeira, according to Oswald Heer, resembles to a certain extent th extinct tertiary flora of Europe.
Hence, we can understand the rule that the mos ancient fossils differ most from existing forms.
Hence, we have only to suppose that such wandering species have bee modified in their new homes in relation to their new position, and we ca understand the presence of endemic bats on oceanic islands, with th absence of all other terrestrial mammals.
Hence, we ma conclude that slight modifications of structure or of instinct, correlate with the sterile condition of certain members of the community, have prove advantageous; consequently the fertile males and females have flourished and transmitted to their fertile offspring a tendency to produce steril members with the same modifications.
Hence, we may conclude that under domestication instincts have bee acquired and natural instincts have been lost, partly by habit and partl by man selecting and accumulating, during successive generations, peculia mental habits and actions, which at first appeared from what we must in ou ignorance call an accident.
Hence, we may conclude that, if insects had not been developed on the fac of the earth, our plants would not have been decked with beautiful flowers but would have produced only such poor flowers as we see on our fir, oak nut and ash trees, on grasses, spinach, docks and nettles, which are al fertilised through the agency of the wind.
Hence, we may look with some confidence t a secure future of great length.
Hence, we may perhaps infer, that during th palaeozoic and secondary periods, neither continents nor continenta islands existed where our oceans now extend; for had they existed palaeozoic and secondary formations would in all probability have bee accumulated from sediment derived from their wear and tear; and would hav been at least partially upheaved by the oscillations of level, which mus have intervened during these enormously long periods.
Hence, we may suppose that th organisms which now live under latitude 60 degrees, lived during th Pliocene period further north, under the Polar Circle, in latitude 66-6 degrees; and that the present arctic productions then lived on the broke land still nearer to the pole.
Hence, we see that certain plants growing on th more lofty mountains of the tropics in all parts of the world, and on th temperate plains of the north and south, are either the same species o varieties of the same species.
Hence, we see why all the species in the same region d at last, if we look to long enough intervals of time, become modified; fo otherwise they would become extinct.
Hence, when a organ, however abnormal it may be, has been transmitted in approximatel the same condition to many modified descendants, as in the case of the win of the bat, it must have existed, according to our theory, for an immens period in nearly the same state; and thus it has come not to be mor variable than any other structure.
Hence, when settled in their ne homes, each kind will have been kept by the others to its proper place an habits, and will consequently have been but little liable to modification.
Hence, when the same specie occurs at the bottom, middle, and top of a formation, the probability i that it has not lived on the same spot during the whole period o deposition, but has disappeared and reappeared, perhaps many times, durin the same geological period.
Hence, when the warmth had fully returned, the same species which had lately lived together on the European and North American lowlands, would again be found in the arctic regions of the Old and Ne Worlds, and on many isolated mountain-summits far distant from each other.
Hence, without rejecting th consideration of the present existence of intermediate gradations betwee any two forms, we shall be led to weigh more carefully and to value highe the actual amount of difference between them.
Henry Crawford came and sat some time with them; and her spirits not being previously in the strongest state, her heart was softened for a while towards him, because he really seemed to feel.
Henry Crawford gone, she could even pity her sister.
Henry Crawford had destroyed her happiness, but he should not know that he had done it; he should not destroy her credit, her appearance, her prosperity, too.
Henry Crawford had too much sense not to feel the worth of good principles in a wife, though he was too little accustomed to serious reflection to know them by their proper name; but when he talked of her having such a steadiness and regularity of conduct, such a high notion of honour, and such an observance of decorum as might warrant any man in the fullest dependence on her faith and integrity, he expressed what was inspired by the knowledge of her being well principled and religious.
Henry Crawford had trifled with her feelings; but she had very long allowed and even sought his attentions, with a jealousy of her sister so reasonable as ought to have been their cure; and now that the conviction of his preference for Maria had been forced on her, she submitted to it without any alarm for Maria's situation, or any endeavour at rational tranquillity for herself.
Henry Crawford was again in the house: he walked up with Dr. Grant, who was anxious to pay his respects to Sir Thomas, and at rather an early hour they were ushered into the breakfast-room, where were most of the family.
Henry Crawford was as much struck with it as any.
Henry Crawford was gone, gone from the house, and within two hours afterwards from the parish; and so ended all the hopes his selfish vanity had raised in Maria and Julia Bertram.
Henry Crawford was in the first glow of another scheme about Thornton Lacey; and not being able to catch Edmund's ear, was detailing it to his fair neighbour with a look of considerable earnestness.
Henry Crawford was ready to take either.
Henry Crawford's chair was the first to be given a direction towards them, and he sat silently observing them for a few minutes; himself, in the meanwhile, observed by Sir Thomas, who was standing in chat with Dr. Grant.
Henry Crawford's retaining her hand at such a moment, a moment of such peculiar proof and importance, was worth ages of doubt and anxiety.
Henry Crawford, ruined by early independence and bad domestic example, indulged in the freaks of a cold-blooded vanity a little too long.
Henry Crawford, who meanwhile had taken up the play, and with seeming carelessness was turning over the first act, soon settled the business.
Henry bowed and thanked her.
Henry could not have afforded her such a house.
Henry is different; he loves to be doing.
Henry was most happy to make it more intelligible, by beginning at an earlier stage, and explaining very particularly what he had done.
Henry, I find, has some idea of going into Norfolk again upon some business that you approve; but this cannot possibly be permitted before the middle of next week; that is, he cannot anyhow be spared till after the 14th, for we have a party that evening.
Henry, who is good-nature itself, has offered to fetch it in his barouche.
Henry, who is in every other respect exactly what a brother should be, who loves me, consults me, confides in me, and will talk to me by the hour together, has never yet turned the page in a letter; and very often it is nothing more than - 'Dear Mary, I am just arrived.
Her acceptance must be as certain as his offer; and yet there were bad feelings still remaining which made the prospect of it most sorrowful to her, independently, she believed, independently of self.
Her account was stated on the wall in the same manner.
Her affections were not acute, nor was her mind tenacious.
Her agitation and alarm exceeded all that was endured by the rest, by the right of a disposition which not even innocence could keep from suffering.
Her astonishment and confusion increased; and though still not knowing how to suppose him serious, she could hardly stand.
Her aunt Bertram had recollected her on this occasion with an unusual degree of wakefulness.
Her aunt did not neglect her: she wrote again and again; they were receiving frequent accounts from Edmund, and these accounts were as regularly transmitted to Fanny, in the same diffuse style, and the same medley of trusts, hopes, and fears, all following and producing each other at haphazard.
Her aunt often expressed a wish for her, but there was no notice, no message from the uncle on whom all depended.
Her aunt was no very methodical narrator, but with the help of some letters to and from Sir Thomas, and what she already knew herself, and could reasonably combine, she was soon able to understand quite as much as she wished of the circumstances attending the story.
Her awe of her uncle, and her dread of taking a liberty with him, made it instantly plain to her what she had to do.
Her beauty and acquirements had held but a second place.
Her behaviour to Mr. Rushworth was careless and cold.
Her brother was not handsome: no, when they first saw him he was absolutely plain, black and plain; but still he was the gentleman, with a pleasing address.
Her brows were slightly bent, her mouth slightly open; her whole attitude so still and settled that Dick could hardly fancy that she breathed.
Her cares are over, and she feels that she may exert all her powers of pleasing without suspicion.
Her cause, meanwhile, went on well.
Her choice is made.
Her comfort in that day's dinner was quite destroyed: she could hardly eat anything; and when Sir Thomas good-humouredly observed that joy had taken away her appetite, she was ready to sink with shame, from the dread of Mr. Crawford's interpretation; for though nothing could have tempted her to turn her eyes to the right hand, where he sat, she felt that his were immediately directed towards her.
Her companions were relieved, but there was no good for her.
Her conscience stopt her in the middle, but Edmund was satisfied.
Her continual disagreements with her mother, her rash squabbles with Tom and Charles, and petulance with Betsey, were at least so distressing to Fanny that, though admitting they were by no means without provocation, she feared the disposition that could push them to such length must be far from amiable, and from affording any repose to herself.
Her correspondence with her aunt Bertram was her only concern of higher interest.
Her cousin Edmund never forgets her.
Her cousins might attack, but could hardly tease her.
Her cousins' former gaiety on the day of a ball was no longer surprising to her; she felt it to be indeed very charming, and was actually practising her steps about the drawing-room as long as she could be safe from the notice of her aunt Norris, who was entirely taken up at first in fresh arranging and injuring the noble fire which the butler had prepared.
Her curiosity was all awake, and she ran through it with an eagerness which was suspended only by intervals of astonishment, that it could be chosen in the present instance, that it could be proposed and accepted in a private theatre! Agatha and Amelia appeared to her in their different ways so totally improper for home representation - the situation of one, and the language of the other, so unfit to be expressed by any woman of modesty, that she could hardly suppose her cousins could be aware of what they were engaging in; and longed to have them roused as soon as possible by the remonstrance which Edmund would certainly make.
Her daughters never had been much to her.
Her days were spent in a kind of slow bustle; all was busy without getting on, always behindhand and lamenting it, without altering her ways; wishing to be an economist, without contrivance or regularity; dissatisfied with her servants, without skill to make them better, and whether helping, or reprimanding, or indulging them, without any power of engaging their respect.
Her dejection had no abatement from anything passing around her; a friend or two of her father's, as always happened if he was not with them, spent the long, long evening there; and from six o'clock till half-past nine, there was little intermission of noise or grog.
Her diffidence, gratitude, and softness made every expression of indifference seem almost an effort of self-denial; seem, at least, to be giving nearly as much pain to herself as to him.
Her disappointment in her mother was greater: there she had hoped much, and found almost nothing.
Her displeasure, her penetration, and her happiness were all fearful to encounter; and the dependence of having others present when they met was Fanny's only support in looking forward to it.
Her disposition was naturally easy and indolent, like Lady Bertram's; and a situation of similar affluence and do-nothingness would have been much more suited to her capacity than the exertions and self-denials of the one which her imprudent marriage had placed her in.
Her disposition was peculiarly calculated to value a fond treatment, and from having hitherto known so little of it, she was the more overcome by Miss Crawford's.
Her eager defence of her brother, her hope of its being hushed up, her evident agitation, were all of a piece with something very bad; and if there was a woman of character in existence, who could treat as a trifle this sin of the first magnitude, who would try to gloss it over, and desire to have it unpunished, she could believe Miss Crawford to be the woman! Now she could see her own mistake as to who were gone, or said to be gone.
Her elder cousins mortified her by reflections on her size, and abashed her by noticing her shyness: Miss Lee wondered at her ignorance, and the maid-servants sneered at her clothes; and when to these sorrows was added the idea of the brothers and sisters among whom she had always been important as playfellow, instructress, and nurse, the despondence that sunk her little heart was severe.
Her eldest was a boy of ten years old, a fine spirited fellow, who longed to be out in the world; but what could she do? Was there any chance of his being hereafter useful to Sir Thomas in the concerns of his West Indian property? No situation would be beneath him; or what did Sir Thomas think of Woolwich? or how could a boy be sent out to the East The letter was not unproductive.
Her enjoyment, however, was for herself alone.
Her exultation and pleasure were so keen and exquisite, and her beauty, so delicate, yet so interfused with energy, expressed it so fully, that any added word would have been commonplace and futile.
Her eye fell everywhere on lawns and plantations of the freshest green; and the trees, though not fully clothed, were in that delightful state when farther beauty is known to be at hand, and when, while much is actually given to the sight, more yet remains for the imagination.
Her eyes brightened at the sight of Edmund.
Her eyes should be darker, but she has a sweet smile; but as for this wonderful degree of improvement, I am sure it may all be resolved into a better style of dress, and your having nobody else to look at; and therefore, if you do set about a flirtation with her, you never will persuade me that it is in compliment to her beauty, or that it proceeds from anything but your own idleness and folly.
Her eyes were so bright that you were never sure if there were tears in them or not; little voluptuous shivers ran about her body; sometimes she nestled her chin into her throat, sometimes threw back her head, with ecstasy; in a word, she was in that state when it is said of people that they cannot contain themselves for happiness.
Her face startled him; it was a face he wanted; and he took it in at once like breathing air.
Her father asked him to do them the honour of taking his mutton with them, and Fanny had time for only one thrill of horror, before he declared himself prevented by a prior engagement.
Her father's house would, in all probability, teach her the value of a good income; and he trusted that she would be the wiser and happier woman, all her life, for the experiment he had devised.
Her features are not tragic features, and she walks too quick, and speaks too quick, and would not keep her countenance.
Her feelings for one and the other were soon a little tranquillised by seeing the party in the meadow disperse, and Miss Crawford still on horseback, but attended by Edmund on foot, pass through a gate into the lane, and so into the park, and make towards the spot where she stood.
Her feelings have been steadily against it from first to last.
Her feelings ought to be respected.
Her feelings were all in revolt.
Her feelings were very acute, and too little understood to be properly attended to.
Her feelings, probably, were not acute; he had never supposed them to be so; but her comforts might not be less on that account; and if she could dispense with seeing her husband a leading, shining character, there would certainly be everything else in her favour.
Her figure is as neat as her brother's.
Her friends leading her astray for years! She is quite as likely to have led them astray.
Her going roused the rest; and at the same moment the two brothers stepped forward, feeling the necessity of doing something.
Her greatest support and glory was in having formed the connexion with the Rushworths.
Her greatest wonder on the subject soon became - not that Susan should have been provoked into disrespect and impatience against her better knowledge -  but that so much better knowledge, so many good notions should have been hers at all; and that, brought up in the midst of negligence and error, she should have formed such proper opinions of what ought to be; she, who had had no cousin Edmund to direct her thoughts or fix her principles.
Her habits of ready submission, on the contrary, made her almost instantly rise and lead the way out of the room.
Her happiness on this occasion was very much a la mortal, finely chequered.
Her heart and her judgment were equally against Edmund's decision: she could not acquit his unsteadiness, and his happiness under it made her wretched.
Her heart and her time were already quite full; she had neither leisure nor affection to bestow on Fanny.
Her heart is made for love and kindness, not for resentment.
Her heart was almost broke by such a picture of what she appeared to him; by such accusations, so heavy, so multiplied, so rising in dreadful gradation! Self-willed, obstinate, selfish, and ungrateful.
Her heart was completely sad at parting.
Her heart was sore and angry, and she was capable only of angry consolations.
Her ideas are not higher than her own fortune may warrant, but they are beyond what our incomes united could authorise.
Her ill opinion of him was founded chiefly on observations, which, for her cousins' sake, she could scarcely dare mention to their father.
Her influence over him had already given him some influence over her.
Her influence, or at least the consciousness and use of it, originated in an act of kindness by Susan, which, after many hesitations of delicacy, she at last worked herself up to.
Her judgment may be quite as safely trusted.
Her looks say, 'I will not like you, I am determined not to like you'; and I say she shall.
Her manner was incurably gentle; and she was not aware how much it concealed the sternness of her purpose.
Her merit in being gifted by Nature with strength and courage was fully appreciated by the Miss Bertrams; her delight in riding was like their own; her early excellence in it was like their own, and they had great pleasure in praising it.
Her mind had been never farther from peace.
Her mind was all disorder.
Her mind was entirely self-engrossed.
Her mind was in too much confusion.
Her mind was quite determined, and varied not.
Her mind, disposition, opinions, and habits wanted no half-concealment, no self-deception on the present, no reliance on future improvement.
Her more fearless disposition and happier nerves made everything easy to her there.
Her mother, however, could not stay long enough to suspect anything.
Her next proposition, of shewing the house to such of them as had not been there before, was more acceptable, for Miss Bertram was pleased to have its size displayed, and all were glad to be doing something.
Her niece thought it perfectly reasonable.
Her only friend was absent.
Her only resource was to get out of the subject as fast as possible, and turn the current of Sir Thomas's ideas into a happier channel.
Her opinion was sought as to the probable continuance of the open weather, but her answers were as short and indifferent as civility allowed.
Her own gentle voice speaking from the other end of the room, which was a very long one, told them that she was on the sofa.
Her own thoughts and reflections were habitually her best companions; and, in observing the appearance of the country, the bearings of the roads, the difference of soil, the state of the harvest, the cottages, the cattle, the children, she found entertainment that could only have been heightened by having Edmund to speak to of what she felt.
Her plants, her books -  of which she had been a collector from the first hour of her commanding a shilling - her writing-desk, and her works of charity and ingenuity, were all within her reach; or if indisposed for employment, if nothing but musing would do, she could scarcely see an object in that room which had not an interesting remembrance connected with it.
Her pleasant manners and cheerful conformity made her always valuable amongst them; but now she was absolutely necessary.
Her poor mother now did not look so very unworthy of being Lady Bertram's sister as she was but too apt to look.
Her praise had been given in her attention; that must content them.
Her praise was warm, and he received it as she could wish, joining in it as far as discretion, and politeness, and slowness of speech would allow, and certainly appearing to greater advantage on the subject than his lady did soon afterwards, when Mary, perceiving her on a sofa very near, turned round before she began to dance, to compliment her on Miss Price's looks.
Her prejudices, I trust, are not so strong as they were.
Her reception of him was of a sort which he could not have hoped for, had he expected to see her.
Her representation of her cousin's state at this time was exactly according to her own belief of it, and such as she supposed would convey to the sanguine mind of her correspondent the hope of everything she was wishing for.
Her secret was still her own; and while that was the case, she thought she could resign herself to almost everything.
Her sensations were indefinable, and so were they a few minutes afterwards upon hearing Henry Crawford, who had a chair between herself and Tom, ask the latter in an undervoice whether there were any plans for resuming the play after the present happy interruption (with a courteous glance at Sir Thomas), because, in that case, he should make a point of returning to Mansfield at any time required by the party: he was going away immediately, being to meet his uncle at Bath without delay; but if there were any prospect of a renewal of Lovers' Vows, he should hold himself positively engaged, he should break through every other claim, he should absolutely condition with his uncle for attending them whenever he might be wanted.
Her sentiments towards him were compounded of all that was respectful, grateful, confiding, and tender.
Her son answered cheerfully, telling her that everything was always for the best; and making light of his own inconvenience in being obliged to hurry away so soon.
Her spirits sank under the glow of theirs, and she felt herself becoming too nearly nothing to both to have any comfort in having been sought by either.
Her spirits were low.
Her store-room, she thought, might have been good enough for Mrs. Grant to go into.
Her story began; and Fanny immediately slipped out of the room; for to hear herself the subject of any discussion with her uncle was more than her nerves could bear.
Her strong black brows spoke of temper easily aroused and hard to quiet; her mouth was small, nervous and weak; there was something dangerous and sulky underlying, in her nature, much that was honest, compassionate, and even noble.
Her talents will be wanted in Amelia.
Her temper he had good reason to depend on and to praise.
Her temper was naturally the easiest of the two; her feelings, though quick, were more controllable, and education had not given her so very hurtful a degree of self-consequence.
Her temper was open.
Her thoughts were all secret; her heart was locked and bolted; and he stood without, vainly wooing her with his eves.
Her tone of calm languor, for she never took the trouble of raising her voice, was always heard and attended to; and Sir Thomas came back.
Her two absent cousins, especially Maria, were much in her thoughts on seeing him; but no embarrassing remembrance affected his spirits.
Her uncle and both her aunts were in the drawing-room when Fanny went down.
Her uncle's behaviour to her was then as nearly as possible what it had been before; she was sure he did not mean there should be any change, and that it was only her own conscience that could fancy any; but her aunt was soon quarrelling with her; and when she found how much and how unpleasantly her having only walked out without her aunt's knowledge could be dwelt on, she felt all the reason she had to bless the kindness which saved her from the same spirit of reproach, exerted on a more momentous subject.
Her uncle's displeasure was terrible to her; but what could her justification or her gratitude and attachment do for him? His stay must be on Edmund alone.
Her uncle's kind expressions, however, and forbearing manner, were sensibly felt; and when she considered how much of the truth was unknown to him, she believed she had no right to wonder at the line of conduct he pursued.
Her vexation did not end with the week.
Her visits there, beginning by chance, were continued by solicitation.
Her voice was calm, her enunciation a little slow, but perfectly distinct, and she stood before him as she spoke, in the simplest and most maidenly attitude.
Here Fanny interposed, however, with anxious protestations of her own equal ignorance; she had never played the game nor seen it played in her life; and Lady Bertram felt a moment's indecision again; but upon everybody's assuring her that nothing could be so easy, that it was the easiest game on the cards, and Henry Crawford's stepping forward with a most earnest request to be allowed to sit between her ladyship and Miss Price, and teach them both, it was so settled; and Sir Thomas, Mrs. Norris, and Dr. and Mrs. Grant being seated at the table of prime intellectual state and dignity, the remaining six, under Miss Crawford's direction, were arranged round the other.
Here Fanny, who had looked up, looked down again.
Here I could enjoy everything without an afterthought of the injustice and miserable toil which made my leisure; the ignorance and dulness of life which went to make my keen appreciation of history; the tyranny and the struggle full of fear and mishap which went to make my romance.

Here everybody was noisy, every voice was loud (excepting, perhaps, her mother's, which resembled the soft monotony of Lady Bertram's, only worn into fretfulness).

Here he was again on the same ground where all had passed before, and apparently as willing to stay and be happy without the Miss Bertrams, as if he had never known Mansfield in any other state.
Here he was at least, and had been any time these past ten years, a sort of dismal parasite upon the foreigner in Paris.

Verlot, some varieties of the double annual stock, fro having been long and carefully selected to the right degree, always produc a large proportion of seedlings bearing double and quite sterile flowers but they likewise yield some single and fertile plants.
Here is a better case:  the leg of a woodcock was sent to me by  friend, with a little cake of dry earth attached to the shank, weighin only nine grains; and this contained a seed of the toad-rush (Juncu bufonius) which germinated and flowered.
Here is a young man of sense, of character, of temper, of manners, and of fortune, exceedingly attached to you, and seeking your hand in the most handsome and disinterested way; and let me tell you, Fanny, that you may live eighteen years longer in the world without being addressed by a man of half Mr. Crawford's estate, or a tenth part of his merits.
Here is a young man wishing to pay his addresses to you, with everything to recommend him: not merely situation in life, fortune, and character, but with more than common agreeableness, with address and conversation pleasing to everybody.

Here was another strange revolution of mind! She was really glad to receive the letter when it did come.

Here was disappointment! Mrs. Grant's non-attendance was sad indeed.
Here was the ghost of London still asserting itself as a centre, - an intellectual centre, for aught I knew.

Hilair apparently entertains no doubt, that the more an organ normally differs i the different species of the same group, the more subject it is t anomalies in the individuals.
Hilaire gives the following cases:  the genu Zanthoxylon belongs to a division of the Rutaceae with a single ovary, bu in some species flowers may be found on the same plant, and even in th same panicle, with either one or two ovaries.
Hilaire ha proved this in regard to size, and so it is with colour, and probably wit the length of hair.
Hilaire has forcibly remarked that certain malconformations frequently, an that others rarely, coexist without our being able to assign any reason.
Hilaire has strongly insisted on the high importance o relative position or connexion in homologous parts; they may differ t almost any extent in form and size, and yet remain connected together i the same invariable order.
Hilaire's great work on thi subject.
Hilaire, both wit varieties and species, that when any part or organ is repeated many time in the same individual (as the vertebrae in snakes, and the stamens i polyandrous flowers) the number is variable; whereas the number of the sam part or organ, when it occurs in lesser numbers, is constant.

His business in Antigua had latterly been prosperously rapid, and he came directly from Liverpool, having had an opportunity of making his passage thither in a private vessel, instead of waiting for the packet; and all the little particulars of his proceedings and events, his arrivals and departures, were most promptly delivered, as he sat by Lady Bertram and looked with heartfelt satisfaction on the faces around him - interrupting himself more than once, however, to remark on his good fortune in finding them all at home - coming unexpectedly as he did -  all collected together exactly as he could have wished, but dared not depend on.
His business was so nearly concluded as to justify him in proposing to take his passage in the September packet, and he consequently looked forward with the hope of being with his beloved family again early in November.

His manners now, though not polished, were more than passable: they were grateful, animated, manly; his expressions were those of an attached father, and a sensible man; his loud tones did very well in the open air, and there was not a single oath to be heard.
His mind was fagged, and her happiness sprung from being the friend with whom it could find repose.
His mind, now disengaged from the cares which had pressed on him at first, was at leisure to find the Grants and their young inmates really worth visiting; and though infinitely above scheming or contriving for any the most advantageous matrimonial establishment that could be among the apparent possibilities of any one most dear to him, and disdaining even as a littleness the being quick-sighted on such points, he could not avoid perceiving, in a grand and careless way, that Mr. Crawford was somewhat distinguishing his niece -  nor perhaps refrain (though unconsciously) from giving a more willing assent to invitations on that account.

His opinion of her had been sinking from the day of his return from Antigua: in every transaction together from that period, in their daily intercourse, in business, or in chat, she had been regularly losing ground in his esteem, and convincing him that either time had done her much disservice, or that he had considerably over-rated her sense, and wonderfully borne with her manners before.

His recitals were amusing in themselves to Sir Thomas, but the chief object in seeking them was to understand the reciter, to know the young man by his histories; and he listened to his clear, simple, spirited details with full satisfaction, seeing in them the proof of good principles, professional knowledge, energy, courage, and cheerfulness, everything that could deserve or promise well.
His scheme was to rent the house himself the following winter, that he might have a home of his own in that neighbourhood; and it was not merely for the use of it in the hunting-season (as he was then telling her), though that consideration had certainly some weight, feeling as he did that, in spite of all Dr. Grant's very great kindness, it was impossible for him and his horses to be accommodated where they now were without material inconvenience; but his attachment to that neighbourhood did not depend upon one amusement or one season of the year: he had set his heart upon having a something there that he could come to at any time, a little homestall at his command, where all the holidays of his year might be spent, and he might find himself continuing, improving, and perfecting that friendship and intimacy with the Mansfield Park family which was increasing in value to him every day.

How inexplicable are the cases of serial homologies on the ordinary view o creation!  Why should the brain be enclosed in a box composed of suc numerous and such extraordinarily shaped pieces of bone apparentl representing vertebrae?  As Owen has remarked, the benefit derived from th yielding of the separate pieces in the act of parturition by mammals, wil by no means explain the same construction in the skulls of birds an reptiles.
How inexplicable o the theory of creation is the occasional appearance of stripes on th shoulders and legs of the several species of the horse-genus and of thei hybrids!  How simply is this fact explained if we believe that thes species are all descended from a striped progenitor, in the same manner a the several domestic breeds of the pigeon are descended from the blue an barred rock-pigeon On the ordinary view of each species having been independently created, wh should specific characters, or those by which the species of the same genu differ from each other, be more variable than the generic characters i which they all agree?  Why, for instance, should the colour of a flower b more likely to vary in any one species of a genus, if the other specie possess differently coloured flowers, than if all possessed the sam coloured flowers?  If species are only well-marked varieties, of which th characters have become in a high degree permanent, we can understand thi fact; for they have already varied since they branched off from a commo progenitor in certain characters, by which they have come to b specifically distinct from each other; therefore these same character would be more likely again to vary than the generic characters which hav been inherited without change for an immense period.

How, then, can we explain these several facts in embryology - namely, th very general, though not universal, difference in structure between th embryo and the adult; the various parts in the same individual embryo which ultimately become very unlike, and serve for diverse purposes, bein at an early period of growth alike; the common, but not invariable resemblance between the embryos or larvae of the most distinct species in the same class; the embryo often retaining, while within the egg or womb structures which are of no service to it, either at that or at a late period of life; on the other hand, larvae which have to provide for thei own wants, being perfectly adapted to the surrounding conditions; an lastly, the fact of certain larvae standing higher in the scale o organisation than the mature animal into which they are developed?   believe that all these facts can be explained as follows.

Hybrid plants produced from a reciprocal cross generally resemble eac other closely, and so it is with mongrel plants from a reciprocal cross.
Hybrids are seldom raised b experimentalists in great numbers; and as the parent-species, or othe allied hybrids, generally grow in the same garden, the visits of insect must be carefully prevented during the flowering season:  hence hybrids, i left to themselves, will generally be fertilised during each generation b pollen from the same flower; and this would probably be injurious to thei fertility, already lessened by their hybrid origin.
Hybrids, however, are differently circumstanced before and afte birth:  when born and living in a country where their two parents live they are generally placed under suitable conditions of life.
Hybrids, on the other hand, have their reproductive organs functionall impotent, as may be clearly seen in the state of the male element in bot plants and animals; though the formative organs themselves are perfect i structure, as far as the microscope reveals.
Hydrometers are tested by careful immersion in pure distilled water; of which the specific gravity is taken as unity.

I all cases of beings, far removed from each other in the scale o organisation, which are furnished with similar and peculiar organs, it wil be found that although the general appearance and function of the organ may be the same, yet fundamental differences between them can always b detected.
I all cases there are two factors, the nature of the organism, which is muc the most important of the two, and the nature of the conditions.
I all such cases one of the two organs might readily be modified an perfected so as to perform all the work, being aided during the progress o modification by the other organ; and then this other organ might b modified for some other and quite distinct purpose, or be wholl obliterated.

I believe it was intended to pull them down quite at the beginning of our days; but there was, I am told, a queer antiquarian society, which had done some service in past times, and which straightway set up its pipe against their destruction, as it has done with many other buildings, which most people looked upon as worthless, and public nuisances; and it was so energetic, and had such good reasons to give, that it generally gained its point; and I must say that when all is said I am glad of it: because you know at the worst these silly old buildings serve as a kind of foil to the beautiful ones which we build now.
I believe that animals are descende from at most only four or five progenitors, and plants from an equal o lesser number.
I believe that the ARRANGEMEN of the groups within each class, in due subordination and relation to eac other, must be strictly genealogical in order to be natural; but that th AMOUNT of difference in the several branches or groups, though allied i the same degree in blood to their common progenitor, may differ greatly being due to the different degrees of modification which they hav undergone; and this is expressed by the forms being ranked under differen genera, families, sections or orders.
I believe that this is the case and that community of descent - the one known cause of close similarity i organic beings - is the bond, which, though observed by various degrees o modification, is partially revealed to us by our classifications.

I cured him at last; but he was very bad all the winter - and this was such a day, I could not help going to him up in his room before we set off to advise him not to venture: he was putting on his wig; so I said, 'Coachman, you had much better not go; your Lady and I shall be very safe; you know how steady Stephen is, and Charles has been upon the leaders so often now, that I am sure there is no fear.' But, however, I soon found it would not do; he was bent upon going, and as I hate to be worrying and officious, I said no more; but my heart quite ached for him at every jolt, and when we got into the rough lanes about Stoke, where, what with frost and snow upon beds of stones, it was worse than anything you can imagine, I was quite in an agony about him.
I dare say I was not reasonable in carrying with me hopes of an intercourse at all like that of Mansfield.
I dare say Mr. Crawford would take my two nieces and me in his barouche, and Edmund can go on horseback, you know, sister, and Fanny will stay at home with you.
I dare say she would not; but she would be introduced into the society of this country under such very favourable circumstances as, in all human probability, would get her a creditable establishment.
I dare say that, on a comparison of our opinions, they would be found as much alike as they have been used to be: to the point - I consider Crawford's proposals as most advantageous and desirable, if you could return his affection.
I dare say there is always some reputable tradesman's wife or other going up.
I dare say they are trying for it.
I daresay old Hammond would give you plenty of information in detail about it.
I daresay you remember that the Bishop of Ely's house is mentioned in Shakespeare's play of King Richard III.; and there are some remains of that still left.
I declare, when I got back to Sotherton yesterday, it looked like a prison -  quite a dismal old prison.
I deferred it all till his praise should be proved the praise of a friend, as this day does prove it.

I did indeed.

I did not think much of it at first - but, upon my word.
I did, at any rate, when I was younger; but now I think I should like it cooler.

Has the little variability of the ass and goose, or the smal power of endurance of warmth by the reindeer, or of cold by the commo camel, prevented their domestication?  I cannot doubt that if other animal and plants, equal in number to our domesticated productions, and belongin to equally diverse classes and countries, were taken from a state o nature, and could be made to breed for an equal number of generations unde domestication, they would on an average vary as largely as the paren species of our existing domesticated productions have varied.

I endeavoured to consult the simplicity of your taste; but, at any rate, I know you will be kind to my intentions, and consider it, as it really is, a token of the love of one of your oldest friends.

I endeavoured, also, to show that intermediat varieties, from existing in lesser numbers than the forms which the connect, will generally be beaten out and exterminated during the course o further modification and improvement.

I further attempted to sho that from the varying descendants of each species trying to occupy as man and as different places as possible in the economy of nature, the constantly tend to diverge in character.

I hav chosen this example because the explanation which most naturalists woul advance is not here applicable, namely, that specific characters are mor variable than generic, because they are taken from parts of les physiological importance than those commonly used for classing genera.
I hav found it difficult, when looking at any two species, to avoid picturing t myself forms DIRECTLY intermediate between them.
I hav given my reasons for believing that most of our great formations, rich i fossils, were deposited during periods of subsidence; and that blan intervals of vast duration, as far as fossils are concerned, occurre during the periods when the bed of the sea was either stationary or rising and likewise when sediment was not thrown down quickly enough to embed an preserve organic remains.
I have a great mind to go back into Norfolk directly, and put everything at once on such a footing as cannot be afterwards swerved from.
I have a much greater respect for those that are honest and rich.
I have already endeavoured to explain how plants became twiners, namely, b the increase of a tendency to slight and irregular revolving movements which were at first of no use to them; this movement, as well as that du to a touch or shake, being the incidental result of the power of moving gained for other and beneficial purposes.
I have already given my reason for disbelieving in continental extensions within the period of existin species on so enormous a scale that all the many islands of the severa oceans were thus stocked with their present terrestrial inhabitants.
I have already recapitulated, as fairly as I could, the oppose difficulties and objections:  now let us turn to the special facts an arguments in favour of the theory.
I have als found that the visits of bees are necessary for the fertilisation of som kinds of clover; for instance twenty heads of Dutch clover (Trifoliu repens) yielded 2,290 seeds, but twenty other heads, protected from bees produced not one.
I have als shown that the intermediate varieties which probably at first existed i the intermediate zones, would be liable to be supplanted by the allie forms on either hand; for the latter, from existing in greater numbers would generally be modified and improved at a quicker rate than th intermediate varieties, which existed in lesser numbers; so that th intermediate varieties would, in the long run, be supplanted an exterminated.
I have also consulted som sagacious and experienced observers, and, after deliberation, they concu in this view.

I have always found you a very good girl.

I have as yet spoken as if the varieties of the same species wer invariably fertile when intercrossed.
I have associated wit several eminent fanciers, and have been permitted to join two of the Londo Pigeon Clubs.
I have attempte to show how much light the principle of gradation throws on the admirabl architectural powers of the hive-bee.
I have attempted to show that the geological record is extremely imperfect that only a small portion of the globe has been geologically explored wit care; that only certain classes of organic beings have been largel preserved in a fossil state; that the number both of specimens and o species, preserved in our museums, is absolutely as nothing compared wit the number of generations which must have passed away even during a singl formation; that, owing to subsidence being almost necessary for th accumulation of deposits rich in fossil species of many kinds, and thic enough to outlast future degradation, great intervals of time must hav elapsed between most of our successive formations; that there has probabl been more extinction during the periods of subsidence, and more variatio during the periods of elevation, and during the latter the record will hav been least perfectly kept; that each single formation has not bee continuously deposited; that the duration of each formation is probabl short compared with the average duration of specific forms; that migratio has played an important part in the first appearance of new forms in an one area and formation; that widely ranging species are those which hav varied most frequently, and have oftenest given rise to new species; tha varieties have at first been local; and lastly, although each species mus have passed through numerous transitional stages, it is probable that th periods, during which each underwent modification, though many and long a measured by years, have been short in comparison with the periods durin which each remained in an unchanged condition.
I have been a devourer of my own.

I have been struck with the fact that if an animal or plant in a state of nature be highly useful to man, or from an cause closely attracts his attention, varieties of it will almos universally be found recorded.

I have called thi principle, by which each slight variation, if useful, is preserved, by th term natural selection, in order to mark its relation to man's power o selection.

I have cut society with a cut direct; I cut it when I was prosperous, and now I reap my reward, and can cut it with dignity in my declension.
I have discussed the probable origin of domestic pigeons at some, yet quit insufficient, length; because when I first kept pigeons and watched th several kinds, well knowing how truly they breed, I felt fully as muc difficulty in believing that since they had been domesticated they had al proceeded from a common parent, as any naturalist could in coming to  similar conclusion in regard to the many species of finches, or othe groups of birds, in nature.

I have made so many experiment and collected so many facts, showing on the one hand that an occasiona cross with a distinct individual or variety increases the vigour an fertility of the offspring, and on the other hand that very clos interbreeding lessens their vigour and fertility, that I cannot doubt th correctness of this conclusion.
I have made these few remarks on trees simply t call attention to the subject.

I have my alarms, but they are quite in a different quarter; and if I could have altered the weather, you would have had a good sharp east wind blowing on you the whole time - for here are some of my plants which Robert will leave out because the nights are so mild, and I know the end of it will be, that we shall have a sudden change of weather, a hard frost setting in all at once, taking everybody (at least Robert) by surprise, and I shall lose every one; and what is worse, cook has just been telling me that the turkey, which I particularly wished not to be dressed till Sunday, because I know how much more Dr. Grant would enjoy it on Sunday after the fatigues of the day, will not keep beyond to-morrow.
I have myself recentl bred a foal from a bay mare (offspring of a Turkoman horse and a Flemis mare) by a bay English race-horse.

I have no fears and no scruples.

I have not time for writing much, but it would be out of place if I had, for this is to be a mere letter of business, penned for the purpose of conveying necessary information, which could not be delayed without risk of evil.
I have not time or patience to give half Henry's messages; be satisfied that the spirit of each and every one is unalterable affection.
I have now been here nearly five months; and, moreover, the quietest five months I ever passed.
I have now considered enough, perhaps more than enough, of the cases selected with care by a skilful naturalist, to prove that natural selectio is incompetent to account for the incipient stages of useful structures and I have shown, as I hope, that there is no great difficulty on thi head.
I have now explained how, I believe, the wonderful fact of two distinctl defined castes of sterile workers existing in the same nest, both widel different from each other and from their parents, has originated.
I have now given the leading facts with respect to rudimentary organs.
I have now recapitulated the facts and considerations which have thoroughl convinced me that species have been modified, during a long course o descent.
I have often heard my old kinsman say the one aim of all people before our time was to avoid work, or at least they thought it was; so of course the work which their daily life forced them to do, seemed more like work than that which they seemed to choose for themselves.
I have often scolded him for it, but it is his only fault; and there is this to be said, that very few young ladies have any affections worth caring for.
I have quite as great an interest in being careful of his house as you can have; and as to such alterations as I was suggesting just now, such as moving a bookcase, or unlocking a door, or even as using the billiard-room for the space of a week without playing at billiards in it, you might just as well suppose he would object to our sitting more in this room, and less in the breakfast-room, than we did before he went away, or to my sister's pianoforte being moved from one side of the room to the other.
I have received an analogous account from Dr. Gunther, who has seen a mouse thus suspend itself.
I have sat invisible beside you many and many a day.
I have seen good actresses fail in the part.

I have several specimens showing clearly that they ca do this.
I have since, sometimes, for a moment, regretted that I did not go back, but I know I was right, and such has been the end of our acquaintance.
I have state that fresh-water fish eat some kinds of seeds, though they reject man other kinds after having swallowed them; even small fish swallow seeds o moderate size, as of the yellow water-lily and Potamogeton.
I have stated in the first chapter, that at whatever age any variatio first appears in the parent, it tends to reappear at a corresponding age i the offspring.
I have stated that the most probable hypothesi to account for the reappearance of very ancient characters, is - that ther is a TENDENCY in the young of each successive generation to produce th long-lost character, and that this tendency, from unknown causes, sometime prevails.
I have such innumerable presents from him that it is quite impossible for me to value or for him to remember half.
I have taken muc pains to ascertain how far they apply to animals, and, considering ho scanty our knowledge is in regard to hybrid animals, I have been surprise to find how generally the same rules apply to both kingdoms.
I have taken pains to verify this assertion, and have found i true, with the exception of New Zealand, New Caledonia, the Andama Islands, and perhaps the Solomon Islands and the Seychelles.
I have the infinite satisfaction of congratulating you on your brother's promotion.
I have three very particular friends who have been all dying for him in their turn; and the pains which they, their mothers (very clever women), as well as my dear aunt and myself, have taken to reason, coax, or trick him into marrying, is inconceivable! He is the most horrible flirt that can be imagined.

I may here recall a remark formerly made, namely, that it might require  long succession of ages to adapt an organism to some new and peculiar lin of life, for instance, to fly through the air; and consequently that th transitional forms would often long remain confined to some one region; bu that, when this adaptation had once been effected, and a few species ha thus acquired a great advantage over other organisms, a comparatively shor time would be necessary to produce many divergent forms, which would sprea rapidly and widely throughout the world.
I may illustrate what  mean by supposing three varieties of sheep to be kept, one adapted to a extensive mountainous region; a second to a comparatively narrow, hill tract; and a third to the wide plains at the base; and that the inhabitant are all trying with equal steadiness and skill to improve their stocks b selection; the chances in this case will be strongly in favour of the grea holders on the mountains or on the plains improving their breeds mor quickly than the small holders on the intermediate narrow, hilly tract; an consequently the improved mountain or plain breed will soon take the plac of the less improved hill breed; and thus the two breeds, which originall existed in greater numbers, will come into close contact with each other without the interposition of the supplanted, intermediate hill variety.
I may mention as a detail worth noticing that not only did there seem to be a great many more birds about of the non-predatory kinds, but their enemies the birds of prey were also commoner.
I may mention as another illustration o the varied habits of this genus, that a Mexican Colaptes has been describe by De Saussure as boring holes into hard wood in order to lay up a store o acorns.
I may recall the well-known fact that in geological treatises published not many years ago, mammals were always spoken of as havin abruptly come in at the commencement of the tertiary series.
I may repeat what I published in 1845, namely, tha to admit that species generally become rare before they become extinct - t feel no surprise at the rarity of a species, and yet to marvel greatly whe the species ceases to exist, is much the same as to admit that sickness i the individual is the forerunner of death - to feel no surprise at sickness but, when the sick man dies, to wonder and to suspect that he died by som deed of violence.

I noticed both with these pretty girls and with everybody else we met, that in default of serious news, such as we had heard at Maple-Durham, they were eager to discuss all the little details of life: the weather, the hay-crop, the last new house, the plenty or lack of such and such birds, and so on; and they talked of these things not in a fatuous and conventional way, but as taking, I say, real interest in them.

I we admire the truly wonderful power of scent by which the males of man insects find their females, can we admire the production for this singl purpose of thousands of drones, which are utterly useless to the communit for any other purpose, and which are ultimately slaughtered by thei industrious and sterile sisters?  It may be difficult, but we ought t admire the savage instinctive hatred of the queen-bee, which urges her t destroy the young queens, her daughters, as soon as they are born, or t perish herself in the combat; for undoubtedly this is for the good of th community; and maternal love or maternal hatred, though the latte fortunately is most rare, is all the same to the inexorable principles o natural selection.
I we forget for an instant that each species tends to increase inordinately and that some check is always in action, yet seldom perceived by us, th whole economy of nature will be utterly obscured.

If under changing conditions of life organic beings present individua differences in almost every part of their structure, and this cannot b disputed; if there be, owing to their geometrical rate of increase,  severe struggle for life at some age, season or year, and this certainl cannot be disputed; then, considering the infinite complexity of th relations of all organic beings to each other and to their conditions o life, causing an infinite diversity in structure, constitution, and habits to be advantageous to them, it would be a most extraordinary fact if n variations had ever occurred useful to each being's own welfare, in th same manner as so many variations have occurred useful to man.

If we take as the standard of high organisation, the amount o differentiation and specialisation of the several organs in each being whe adult (and this will include the advancement of the brain for intellectua purposes), natural selection clearly leads towards this standard:  for al physiologists admit that the specialisation of organs, inasmuch as in thi state they perform their functions better, is an advantage to each being and hence the accumulation of variations tending towards specialisation i within the scope of natural selection.
If we thus argue in a circle, the fertility of all varietie produced under nature will assuredly have to be granted.

In the case of varieties of the same species, the struggle will generall be almost equally severe, and we sometimes see the contest soon decided: for instance, if several varieties of wheat be sown together, and the mixe seed be resown, some of the varieties which best suit the soil or climate or are naturally the most fertile, will beat the others and so yield mor seed, and will consequently in a few years supplant the other varieties.

It was now about the middle of the afternoon, warm rather than hot, and quite windless; the clouds high up and light, pearly white, and gleaming, softened the sun's burning, but did not hide the pale blue in most places, though they seemed to give it height and consistency; the sky, in short, looked really like a vault, as poets have sometimes called it, and not like mere limitless air, but a vault so vast and full of light that it did not in any way oppress the spirits.

It was really March; but it was April in its mild air, brisk soft wind, and bright sun, occasionally clouded for a minute; and everything looked so beautiful under the influence of such a sky, the effects of the shadows pursuing each other on the ships at Spithead and the island beyond, with the ever-varying hues of the sea, now at high water, dancing in its glee and dashing against the ramparts with so fine a sound, produced altogether such a combination of charms for Fanny, as made her gradually almost careless of the circumstances under which she felt them.

Lady Bertram did not at all like to have her husband leave her; but she was not disturbed by any alarm for his safety, or solicitude for his comfort, being one of those persons who think nothing can be dangerous, or difficult, or fatiguing to anybody but themselves.
Lady Bertram did not go into public with her daughters.
Lady Bertram did not think deeply, but, guided by Sir Thomas, she thought justly on all important points; and she saw, therefore, in all its enormity, what had happened, and neither endeavoured herself, nor required Fanny to advise her, to think little of guilt and infamy.
Lady Bertram did: she entirely agreed with her son as to the necessity of it, and as to its being considered necessary by his father; she only pleaded against there being any hurry; she only wanted him to wait till Sir Thomas's return, and then Sir Thomas might settle it all himself.

Lastly, many grea deposits, requiring a vast length of time for their accumulation, ar entirely destitute of organic remains, without our being able to assign an reason:  one of the most striking instances is that of the Flysc formation, which consists of shale and sandstone, several thousand occasionally even six thousand feet in thickness, and extending for a least 300 miles from Vienna to Switzerland; and although this great mas has been most carefully searched, no fossils, except a few vegetabl remains, have been found.

Look at the Mustel vison of North America, which has webbed feet, and which resembles an otte in its fur, short legs, and form of tail; during summer this animal dive for and preys on fish, but during the long winter it leaves the froze waters, and preys, like other polecats on mice and land animals.

Richardson has remarked, with the posterior part of their bodies rathe wide and with the skin on their flanks rather full, to the so-called flyin squirrels; and flying squirrels have their limbs and even the base of th tail united by a broad expanse of skin, which serves as a parachute an allows them to glide through the air to an astonishing distance from tre to tree.

Moreover, the specie of the larger genera, which afford the greater number of varieties o incipient species, retain to a certain degree the character of varieties for they differ from each other by a less amount of difference than do th species of smaller genera.

Mr. Rushworth had been gone at this time to Bath, to pass a few days with his mother, and bring her back to town, and Maria was with these friends without any restraint, without even Julia; for Julia had removed from Wimpole Street two or three weeks before, on a visit to some relations of Sir Thomas; a removal which her father and mother were now disposed to attribute to some view of convenience on Mr. Yates's account.
Mr. Rushworth had set off early with the great news for Sotherton; and she had fondly hoped for such an immediate eclaircissement as might save him the trouble of ever coming back again.

Mr. Rushworth is never remiss.
Mr. Rushworth is quite right, I think, in meaning to give it a modern dress, and I have no doubt that it will be all done extremely well.

Mr. Rushworth must and would improve in good society; and if Maria could now speak so securely of her happiness with him, speaking certainly without the prejudice, the blindness of love, she ought to be believed.

Mr. Rushworth was at the door to receive his fair lady; and the whole party were welcomed by him with due attention.
Mr. Rushworth was eager to assure her ladyship of his acquiescence, and tried to make out something complimentary; but, between his submission to her taste, and his having always intended the same himself, with the superadded objects of professing attention to the comfort of ladies in general, and of insinuating that there was one only whom he was anxious to please, he grew puzzled, and Edmund was glad to put an end to his speech by a proposal of wine.
Mr. Rushworth was from the first struck with the beauty of Miss Bertram, and, being inclined to marry, soon fancied himself in love.
Mr. Rushworth was not forgotten: a most friendly reception and warmth of hand-shaking had already met him, and with pointed attention he was now included in the objects most intimately connected with Mansfield.
