Mr. Salter has recently given the results o an examination of about 500 eggs produced from various crosses betwee three species of Gallus and their hybrids; the majority of these eggs ha been fertilised; and in the majority of the fertilised eggs, the embryo had either been partially developed and had then perished, or had becom nearly mature, but the young chickens had been unable to break through th shell.
Mr. Scott also has experimented on the species and varieties of Verbascum; an although unable to confirm Gartner's results on the crossing of th distinct species, he finds that the dissimilarly coloured varieties of th same species yield fewer seeds, in the proportion of eighty-six to 100 than the similarly coloured varieties.
Mr. Swaysland, of Brighton, wh during the last forty years has paid close attention to our migrator birds, informs me that he has often shot wagtails (Motacillae), wheatears and whinchats (Saxicolae), on their first arrival on our shores, befor they had alighted; and he has several times noticed little cakes of eart attached to their feet.
Mr. Thwaites informs me that h has observed similar facts in Ceylon; analogous observations have been mad by Mr. H.C. Watson on European species of plants brought from the Azores t England; and I could give other cases.
Mr. Wallace has also detected one such cas with birds, but we have none with the larger quadrupeds.
Mr. Wallace, for instance, describes a certain butterfly whic presents in the same island a great range of varieties connected b intermediate links, and the extreme links of the chain closely resemble th two forms of an allied dimorphic species inhabiting another part of th Malay Archipelago.
Mr. Walsh ranks the forms which i may be supposed would freely intercross, as varieties; and those whic appear to have lost this power, as species.
Mr. Waterhouse has remarked that when a member belonging to one group o animals exhibits an affinity to a quite distinct group, this affinity i most cases is general and not special:  thus, according to Mr. Waterhouse of all Rodents, the bizcacha is most nearly related to Marsupials; but i the points in which it approaches this order, its relations are general that is, not to any one Marsupial species more than to another.
Mr. Watson has also objected that the continued action of natura selection, together with divergence of character, would tend to make a indefinite number of specific forms.
Mr. Windsor Earl ha made some striking observations on this head, since greatly extended by Mr. Wallace's admirable researches, in regard to the great Malay Archipelago which is traversed near Celebes by a space of deep ocean, and thi separates two widely distinct mammalian faunas.
Mr. Wollaston ha discovered the remarkable fact that 200 beetles, out of the 550 specie (but more are now known) inhabiting Madeira, are so far deficient in wing that they cannot fly; and that, of the twenty-nine endemic genera, no les than twenty-three have all their species in this condition!  Several facts namely, that beetles in many parts of the world are very frequently blow to sea and perish; that the beetles in Madeira, as observed by Mr. Wollaston, lie much concealed, until the wind lulls and the sun shines that the proportion of wingless beetles is larger on the exposed Deserta than in Madeira itself; and especially the extraordinary fact, so strongl insisted on by Mr. Wollaston, that certain large groups of beetles elsewhere excessively numerous, which absolutely require the use of thei wings, are here almost entirely absent.
Mr. Woodward has shown that the same law holds good wit sea-shells, but, from the wide distribution of most molluscs, it is no well displayed by them.
Mr. Yates had staid to see the destruction of every theatrical preparation at Mansfield, the removal of everything appertaining to the play: he left the house in all the soberness of its general character; and Sir Thomas hoped, in seeing him out of it, to be rid of the worst object connected with the scheme, and the last that must be inevitably reminding him of its existence.
Mr. Yates took the subject from his friend as soon as possible, and immediately gave Sir Thomas an account of what they had done and were doing: told him of the gradual increase of their views, the happy conclusion of their first difficulties, and present promising state of affairs; relating everything with so blind an interest as made him not only totally unconscious of the uneasy movements of many of his friends as they sat, the change of countenance, the fidget, the hem! of unquietness, but prevented him even from seeing the expression of the face on which his own eyes were fixed - from seeing Sir Thomas's dark brow contract as he looked with inquiring earnestness at his daughters and Edmund, dwelling particularly on the latter, and speaking a language, a remonstrance, a reproof, which he felt at his heart.
Mr. Yates was beginning now to understand Sir Thomas's intentions, though as far as ever from understanding their source.
Mr. Yates was particularly pleased: he had been sighing and longing to do the Baron at Ecclesford, had grudged every rant of Lord Ravenshaw's, and been forced to re-rant it all in his own room.
Mr. Yates's convenience had had nothing to do with it.

Mrs. Grant, hearing the latter part of this speech, enforced it warmly, persuaded that no judgment could be equal to her brother's; and as Miss Bertram caught at the idea likewise, and gave it her full support, declaring that, in her opinion, it was infinitely better to consult with friends and disinterested advisers, than immediately to throw the business into the hands of a professional man, Mr. Rushworth was very ready to request the favour of Mr. Crawford's assistance; and Mr. Crawford, after properly depreciating his own abilities, was quite at his service in any way that could be useful.
Mrs. Grant, really eager to get any change for her sister, could, by the easiest self-deceit, persuade herself that she was doing the kindest thing by Fanny, and giving her the most important opportunities of improvement in pressing her frequent calls.
Mrs. Grant, with a temper to love and be loved, must have gone with some regret from the scenes and people she had been used to; but the same happiness of disposition must in any place, and any society, secure her a great deal to enjoy, and she had again a home to offer Mary; and Mary had had enough of her own friends, enough of vanity, ambition, love, and disappointment in the course of the last half-year, to be in need of the true kindness of her sister's heart, and the rational tranquillity of her ways.

Mrs. Norris felt herself defrauded of an office on which she had always depended, whether his arrival or his death were to be the thing unfolded; and was now trying to be in a bustle without having anything to bustle about, and labouring to be important where nothing was wanted but tranquillity and silence.
Mrs. Norris fetched breath, and went on again.
Mrs. Norris had been talking to her the whole way from Northampton of her wonderful good fortune, and the extraordinary degree of gratitude and good behaviour which it ought to produce, and her consciousness of misery was therefore increased by the idea of its being a wicked thing for her not to be happy.
Mrs. Norris had been too well employed to move faster.

Mrs. Norris took possession of the White House, the Grants arrived at the Parsonage, and these events over, everything at Mansfield went on for some time as usual.
Mrs. Norris was a little confounded and as nearly being silenced as ever she had been in her life; for she was ashamed to confess having never seen any of the impropriety which was so glaring to Sir Thomas, and would not have admitted that her influence was insufficient -  that she might have talked in vain.
Mrs. Norris was all delight and volubility; and even Fanny had something to say in admiration, and might be heard with complacency.
Mrs. Norris was by no means to be compared in happiness to her sister.
Mrs. Norris was left to settle the matter by herself; and it ended, to the infinite joy of her nephew and niece, in the recollection that she could not possibly be spared from Mansfield Park at present; that she was a great deal too necessary to Sir Thomas and Lady Bertram for her to be able to answer it to herself to leave them even for a week, and therefore must certainly sacrifice every other pleasure to that of being useful to them.
Mrs. Norris was most zealous in promoting the match, by every suggestion and contrivance likely to enhance its desirableness to either party; and, among other means, by seeking an intimacy with the gentleman's mother, who at present lived with him, and to whom she even forced Lady Bertram to go through ten miles of indifferent road to pay a morning visit.
Mrs. Norris was obliged to be satisfied with thinking just the same, and with having been on the point of proposing the 22nd herself, as by far the best day for the purpose.
Mrs. Norris was often observing to the others that she could not get her poor sister and her family out of her head, and that, much as they had all done for her, she seemed to be wanting to do more; and at length she could not but own it to be her wish that poor Mrs. Price should be relieved from the charge and expense of one child entirely out of her great number.
Mrs. Norris was quite at his service; and though she perfectly agreed with him as to its being a most difficult thing, encouraged him to hope that between them it would be easily managed.

Mrs. Norris, most happy to assist in the duties of the day, by spending it at the Park to support her sister's spirits, and drinking the health of Mr. and Mrs. Rushworth in a supernumerary glass or two, was all joyous delight; for she had made the match; she had done everything; and no one would have supposed, from her confident triumph, that she had ever heard of conjugal infelicity in her life, or could have the smallest insight into the disposition of the niece who had been brought up under her eye.
Mrs. Norris, much discontented, was obliged to compose herself to work again; and Fanny, walking off in agitating consciousness, found herself, as she anticipated, in another minute alone with Mr. Crawford.
Mrs. Norris, on quitting the Parsonage, removed first to the Park, and afterwards to a small house of Sir Thomas's in the village, and consoled herself for the loss of her husband by considering that she could do very well without him; and for her reduction of income by the evident necessity of stricter economy.
Mrs. Norris, who had begun to redden, was appeased; and, for a little while, other subjects took place of the improvements of Sotherton.
Mrs. Norris, whose attachment seemed to augment with the demerits of her niece, would have had her received at home and countenanced by them all.
Mrs. Price did quite as much for Lady Bertram as Lady Bertram would have done for Mrs. Price.
Mrs. Price seemed rather surprised that a girl should be fixed on, when she had so many fine boys, but accepted the offer most thankfully, assuring them of her daughter's being a very well-disposed, good-humoured girl, and trusting they would never have cause to throw her off.
Mrs. Price talked of her poor sister for a few minutes, but how to find anything to hold Susan's clothes, because Rebecca took away all the boxes and spoilt them, was much more in her thoughts: and as for Susan, now unexpectedly gratified in the first wish of her heart, and knowing nothing personally of those who had sinned, or of those who were sorrowing - if she could help rejoicing from beginning to end, it was as much as ought to be expected from human virtue at fourteen.
Mrs. Price took her weekly walk on the ramparts every fine Sunday throughout the year, always going directly after morning service and staying till dinner-time.
Mrs. Price was not unkind; but, instead of gaining on her affection and confidence, and becoming more and more dear, her daughter never met with greater kindness from her than on the first day of her arrival.
Mrs. Price's manners were also at their best.
Mrs. Price, Rebecca, and Betsey all went up to defend themselves, all talking together, but Rebecca loudest, and the job was to be done as well as it could in a great hurry; William trying in vain to send Betsey down again, or keep her from being troublesome where she was; the whole of which, as almost every door in the house was open, could be plainly distinguished in the parlour, except when drowned at intervals by the superior noise of Sam, Tom, and Charles chasing each other up and down stairs, and tumbling about and hallooing.
Mrs. Price, in her turn, was injured and angry; and an answer, which comprehended each sister in its bitterness, and bestowed such very disrespectful reflections on the pride of Sir Thomas as Mrs. Norris could not possibly keep to herself, put an end to all intercourse between them for a considerable period.
Mrs. Price, it appeared, scarcely ever stirred out of doors, except of a Sunday; she owned she could seldom, with her large family, find time for a walk.

Mrs. Rushworth was quite ready to retire, and make way for the fortunate young woman whom her dear son had selected; and very early in November removed herself, her maid, her footman, and her chariot, with true dowager propriety, to Bath, there to parade over the wonders of Sotherton in her evening parties; enjoying them as thoroughly, perhaps, in the animation of a card-table, as she had ever done on the spot; and before the middle of the same month the ceremony had taken place which gave Sotherton another mistress.

My poor father and I are scarce on speaking terms.
My poor sister was forced to stay and bear it.

My uncle meant it so.

My uncle talked of two months.
My uncle, who is the very best man in the world, has exerted himself, as I knew he would, after seeing your brother.

N doubt many organs exist of which we do not know the transitional grades more especially if we look to much-isolated species, around which according to the theory, there has been much extinction.
N doubt small areas can be pointed out in the Old World hotter than any i the New World; but these are not inhabited by a fauna different from tha of the surrounding districts; for it is rare to find a group of organism confined to a small area, of which the conditions are peculiar in only  slight degree.

Nat.
Natural Selection  -  its power compared with man's selection  -  its powe on characters of trifling importance  -  its power at all ages and on bot sexes  -  Sexual Selection  -  On the generality of intercrosses betwee individuals of the same species  -  Circumstances favourable an unfavourable to the results of Natural Selection, namely, intercrossing isolation, number of individuals  -  Slow action  -  Extinction caused b Natural Selection  -  Divergence of Character, related to the diversity o inhabitants of any small area and to naturalisation  -  Action of Natura Selection, through Divergence of Character and Extinction, on th descendants from a common parent  -  Explains the Grouping of all organi beings  -  Advance in organisation  -  Low forms preserved  -  Convergence o character  -  Indefinite multiplication of species  -  Summary.
Natural selectio will not necessarily lead to absolute perfection; nor, as far as we ca judge by our limited faculties, can absolute perfection be everywher predicated.
Natural selection acts exclusively by the preservation and accumulation o variations, which are beneficial under the organic and inorganic condition to which each creature is exposed at all periods of life.
Natural selection acts only by th preservation and accumulation of small inherited modifications, eac profitable to the preserved being; and as modern geology has almos banished such views as the excavation of a great valley by a singl diluvial wave, so will natural selection banish the belief of the continue creation of new organic beings, or of any great and sudden modification i their structure.
Natural selection acts solely through the preservation o variations in some way advantageous, which consequently endure.
Natural selection as has just been remarked, leads to divergence of character and to muc extinction of the less improved and intermediate forms of life.
Natural selection can produce nothing in one species for the exclusive goo or injury of another; though it may well produce parts, organs, an excretions highly useful or even indispensable, or highly injurious t another species, but in all cases at the same time useful to the possessor.
Natural selection cannot possibly produce any modification in a specie exclusively for the good of another species; though throughout nature on species incessantly takes advantage of, and profits by the structures o others.
Natural selection may modify and adapt the larva of a insect to a score of contingencies, wholly different from those whic concern the mature insect; and these modifications may affect, throug correlation, the structure of the adult.
Natural selection tends only to make each organic being as perfect as, o slightly more perfect than the other inhabitants of the same country wit which it comes into competition.
Natural selection will modify the structure of the young in relation to th parent and of the parent in relation to the young.
Natural selection will never produce in a being any structure mor injurious than beneficial to that being, for natural selection acts solel by and for the good of each.
Natural selection will not produce absolut perfection, nor do we always meet, as far as we can judge, with this hig standard under nature.
Natural selection, also, leads to divergence of character; for the mor organic beings diverge in structure, habits and constitution, by so muc the more can a large number be supported on the area, of which we see proo by looking to the inhabitants of any small spot, and to the production naturalised in foreign lands.
Natural selection, it should never b forgotten, can act solely through and for the advantage of each being.
Natural selection, on the principle of qualities being inherited a corresponding ages, can modify the egg, seed, or young as easily as th adult.
Naturalists continually refer to external conditions, such a climate, food, etc., as the only possible cause of variation.
Naturalists frequently speak of the skull as formed of metamorphose vertebrae; the jaws of crabs as metamorphosed legs; the stamens and pistil in flowers as metamorphosed leaves; but it would in most cases be mor correct, as Professor Huxley has remarked, to speak of both skull an vertebrae, jaws and legs, etc., as having been metamorphosed, not one fro the other, as they now exist, but from some common and simpler element.
Naturalists, as we have seen, try to arrange the species, genera an families in each class, on what is called the Natural System.
Nature had given them no inconsiderable share of beauty, and every Sunday dressed them in their cleanest skins and best attire.
Nature may b said to have taken pains to reveal her scheme of modification, by means o rudimentary organs, of embryological and homologous structures, but we ar too blind to understand her meaning.
Nature resisted it for a while.
Nay, had she been without his arm, she would soon have known that she needed it, for she wanted strength for a two hours' saunter of this kind, coming, as it generally did, upon a week's previous inactivity.

On the principle of successive slight variations, not necessarily o generally supervening at a very early period of life, and being inherite at a corresponding period, we can understand the leading facts i embryology; namely, the close resemblance in the individual embryo of th parts which are homologous, and which when matured become widely differen in structure and function; and the resemblance of the homologous parts o organs in allied though distinct species, though fitted in the adult stat for habits as different as is possible.

On the view of characters being of real importance for classification, onl in so far as they reveal descent, we can clearly understand why analogica or adaptive characters, although of the utmost importance to the welfare o the being, are almost valueless to the systematist.
On the view of descent wit modification, we may conclude that the existence of organs in  rudimentary, imperfect, and useless condition, or quite aborted, far fro presenting a strange difficulty, as they assuredly do on the old doctrin of creation, might even have been anticipated in accordance with the view here explained.
On the view of descent with modification, the origin of rudimentary organ is comparatively simple; and we can understand to a large extent the law governing their imperfect development.
On the view of each organism with al its separate parts having been specially created, how utterly inexplicabl is it that organs bearing the plain stamp of inutility, such as the teet in the embryonic calf or the shrivelled wings under the soldere wing-covers of many beetles, should so frequently occur.
On the view of instincts havin been slowly acquired through natural selection, we need not marvel at som instincts being not perfect and liable to mistakes, and at many instinct causing other animals to suffer.
On the view that species are only strongly marked and permanent varieties and that each species first existed as a variety, we can see why it is tha no line of demarcation can be drawn between species, commonly supposed t have been produced by special acts of creation, and varieties which ar acknowledged to have been produced by secondary laws.

Or to state the case in another manner:  the points in which al the species of a genus resemble each other, and in which they differ fro allied genera, are called generic characters; and these characters may b attributed to inheritance from a common progenitor, for it can rarely hav happened that natural selection will have modified several distinc species, fitted to more or less widely different habits, in exactly th same manner:  and as these so-called generic characters have been inherite from before the period when the several species first branched off fro their common progenitor, and subsequently have not varied or come to diffe in any degree, or only in a slight degree, it is not probable that the should vary at the present day.
Or, again, the wolves inhabiting a mountainou district, and those frequenting the lowlands, would naturally be forced t hunt different prey; and from the continued preservation of the individual best fitted for the two sites, two varieties might slowly be formed.
Or, again, we may compare the production of South America south of latitude 35 degrees with those north of 2 degrees, which consequently are separated by a space of ten degrees o latitude, and are exposed to considerably different conditions; yet the are incomparably more closely related to each other than they are to th productions of Australia or Africa under nearly the same climate.

Organs in a rudimentary condition plainly show that an early progenitor ha the organ in a fully developed condition, and this in some cases implies a enormous amount of modification in the descendants.
Organs in this condition will always be somewhat rare for beings thus provided will commonly have been supplanted by thei successors with the same organ in a more perfect state, and consequentl will have become long ago extinct.
Organs now of trifling importance have probably in some cases been of hig importance to an early progenitor, and, after having been slowly perfecte at a former period, have been transmitted to existing species in nearly th same state, although now of very slight use; but any actually injuriou deviations in their structure would of course have been checked by natura selection.

Rudimentary organs in the individuals of the same species are very liabl to vary in the degree of their development and in other respects.
Rudimentary organs may be compared with the letters in a word, stil retained in the spelling, but become useless in the pronunciation, bu which serve as a clue for its derivation.
Rudimentary organs may be utterly aborted; and this implies, that i certain animals or plants, parts are entirely absent which analogy woul lead us to expect to find in them, and which are occasionally found i monstrous individuals.
Rudimentary organs sometimes retai their potentiality:  this occasionally occurs with the mammae of mal mammals, which have been known to become well developed and to secret milk.
Rudimentary organs will speak infallibly with respec to the nature of long-lost structures.
Rudimentary organs, from bein useless, are not regulated by natural selection, and hence are variable.
Rudimentary organs, on the othe hand, are either quite useless, such as teeth which never cut through th gums, or almost useless, such as the wings of an ostrich, which serv merely as sails.
Rudimentary parts, as is generally admitted, are apt to be highly variable.
Rudimentary structures on this view ar as good as, or even sometimes better than other parts of the organisation.

Scrooge closed the window, and examined the door by which the Ghost had entered.
Scrooge could not feel it himself, but this was clearly the case; for though the Ghost sat perfectly motionless, its hair, and skirts, and tassels, were still agitated as by the hot vapour from an oven.
Scrooge crept towards it, trembling as he went; and following the finger, read upon the stone of the neglected grave his own name, Ebenezer Scrooge.
Scrooge expressed himself much obliged, but could not help thinking that a night of unbroken rest would have been more conducive to that end.

Scrooge knew this, by the smart sound its teeth made, when the jaws were brought together by the bandage.
Scrooge listened again, thinking that the explanation might lie here.
Scrooge listened to this dialogue in horror.
Scrooge looked about him for the Ghost, and saw it not.

Scrooge never painted out old Marley's name.

Scrooge said he knew it.
Scrooge said that he would see him - yes, indeed he did.
Scrooge sat with his door wide open, that he might see him come into the Tank.
Scrooge shivered, and wiped the perspiration from his brow.
Scrooge signed it.
Scrooge stopped.
Scrooge then remembered to have heard that ghosts in haunted houses were described as dragging chains.
Scrooge took his melancholy dinner in his usual melancholy tavern; and having read all the newspapers, and beguiled the rest of the evening with his banker's-book, went home to bed.
Scrooge was at first inclined to be surprised that the Spirit should attach importance to conversations apparently so trivial; but feeling assured that they must have some hidden purpose, he set himself to consider what it was likely to be.
Scrooge was his sole executor, his sole administrator, his sole assign, his sole residuary legatee, his sole friend and sole mourner.
Scrooge was not a man to be frightened by echoes.
Scrooge was the Ogre of the family.
Scrooge went to bed again, and thought, and thought, and thought it over and over, and over, and could make nothing of it.
Scrooge's countenance fell almost as low as the Ghost's had done.
