Surprise, consciousness, and pleasure appeared in each of the three on this unexpected meeting; and as Edmund was come on the very same business that had brought Miss Crawford, consciousness and pleasure were likely to be more than momentary in them.
Susan and an attendant girl, whose inferior appearance informed Fanny, to her great surprise, that she had previously seen the upper servant, brought in everything necessary for the meal; Susan looking, as she put the kettle on the fire and glanced at her sister, as if divided between the agreeable triumph of shewing her activity and usefulness, and the dread of being thought to demean herself by such an office.
Susan became the stationary niece, delighted to be so; and equally well adapted for it by a readiness of mind, and an inclination for usefulness, as Fanny had been by sweetness of temper, and strong feelings of gratitude.
Susan could never be spared.
Susan had always behaved pleasantly to herself, but the determined character of her general manners had astonished and alarmed her, and it was at least a fortnight before she began to understand a disposition so totally different from her own.
Susan had an open, sensible countenance; she was like William, and Fanny hoped to find her like him in disposition and goodwill towards herself.
Susan had read nothing, and Fanny longed to give her a share in her own first pleasures, and inspire a taste for the biography and poetry which she delighted in herself.
Susan saw that much was wrong at home, and wanted to set it right.
Susan shewed that she had delicacy: pleased as she was to be mistress of property which she had been struggling for at least two years, she yet feared that her sister's judgment had been against her, and that a reproof was designed her for having so struggled as to make the purchase necessary for the tranquillity of the house.
Susan too was a grievance.
Susan tried to be useful, where she could only have gone away and cried; and that Susan was useful she could perceive; that things, bad as they were, would have been worse but for such interposition, and that both her mother and Betsey were restrained from some excesses of very offensive indulgence and vulgarity.
Susan was always ready to hear and to sympathise.
Susan was growing very fond of her, and though without any of the early delight in books which had been so strong in Fanny, with a disposition much less inclined to sedentary pursuits, or to information for information's sake, she had so strong a desire of not appearing ignorant, as, with a good clear understanding, made her a most attentive, profitable, thankful pupil.
Susan was her only companion and listener on this, as on more common occasions.
Susan was only acting on the same truths, and pursuing the same system, which her own judgment acknowledged, but which her more supine and yielding temper would have shrunk from asserting.
Susan, she found, looked up to her and wished for her good opinion; and new as anything like an office of authority was to Fanny, new as it was to imagine herself capable of guiding or informing any one, she did resolve to give occasional hints to Susan, and endeavour to exercise for her advantage the juster notions of what was due to everybody, and what would be wisest for herself, which her own more favoured education had fixed in her.
Susan, who had an innate taste for the genteel and well-appointed, was eager to hear, and Fanny could not but indulge herself in dwelling on so beloved a theme.
Susan, you should have taken care of the fire.
Suspense must be submitted to, and must not be allowed to wear her out, and make her useless.
Systematists will be able to pursue their labours as at present but they will not be incessantly haunted by the shadowy doubt whether thi or that form be a true species.
Systematists will have only to decide (not that this will be easy) whethe any form be sufficiently constant and distinct from other forms, to b capable of definition; and if definable, whether the differences b sufficiently important to deserve a specific name.
T admit this view is, as it seems to me, to reject a real for an unreal, o at least for an unknown cause.

Th Malay Archipelago is about the size of Europe from the North Cape to th Mediterranean, and from Britain to Russia; and therefore equals all th geological formations which have been examined with any accuracy, exceptin those of the United States of America.
Th Melipona itself is intermediate in structure between the hive and humbl bee, but more nearly related to the latter:  it forms a nearly regula waxen comb of cylindrical cells, in which the young are hatched, and, i addition, some large cells of wax for holding honey.
Th Pleuronectidae, while very young and still symmetrical, with their eye standing on opposite sides of the head, cannot long retain a vertica position, owing to the excessive depth of their bodies, the small size o their lateral fins, and to their being destitute of a swim-bladder.
Th acquisition of a useless part can hardly be said to raise an organism i the natural scale; and in the case of the imperfect, closed flowers, abov described, if any new principle has to be invoked, it must be one o retrogression rather than of progression; and so it must be with man parasitic and degraded animals.
Th bees, of course, no more knowing that they swept their spheres at on particular distance from each other, than they know what are the severa angles of the hexagonal prisms and of the basal rhombic plates; the motiv power of the process of natural selection having been the construction o cells of due strength and of the proper size and shape for the larvae, thi being effected with the greatest possible economy of labour and wax; tha individual swarm which thus made the best cells with least labour, an least waste of honey in the secretion of wax, having succeeded best, an having transmitted their newly-acquired economical instincts to new swarms which in their turn will have had the best chance of succeeding in th struggle for existence.
Th belief that any given structure, which we think, often erroneously, woul have been beneficial to a species, would have been gained under al circumstances through natural selection, is opposed to what we ca understand of its manner of action.
Th bones of a limb might be shortened and flattened to any extent, becoming a the same time enveloped in thick membrane, so as to serve as a fin; or  webbed hand might have all its bones, or certain bones, lengthened to an extent, with the membrane connecting them increased, so as to serve as  wing; yet all these modifications would not tend to alter the framework o the bones or the relative connexion of the parts.
Th calf, for instance, has inherited teeth, which never cut through the gum of the upper jaw, from an early progenitor having well-developed teeth; an we may believe, that the teeth in the mature animal were formerly reduce by disuse owing to the tongue and palate, or lips, having becom excellently fitted through natural selection to browse without their aid whereas in the calf, the teeth have been left unaffected, and on th principle of inheritance at corresponding ages have been inherited from  remote period to the present day.
Th cause of the original variability of these characters is not manifest; bu we can see why they should not have been rendered as constant and unifor as others, for they are accumulated by sexual selection, which is les rigid in its action than ordinary selection, as it does not entail death but only gives fewer offspring to the less favoured males.
Th common gooseberry, for instance, cannot be grafted on the currant, wherea the currant will take, though with difficulty, on the gooseberry.
Th curious case of Sitaris - a beetle which passes through certain unusua stages of development - will illustrate how this might occur.
Th currents, from their course, would never bring seeds from North America t Britain, though they might and do bring seeds from the West Indies to ou western shores, where, if not killed by their very long immersion in sal water, they could not endure our climate.
Th difference in the length of the corolla in the two kinds of clover, whic determines the visits of the hive-bee, must be very trifling; for I hav been assured that when red clover has been mown, the flowers of the secon crop are somewhat smaller, and that these are visited by many hive-bees.
Th difficulty is the same as that felt by so many geologists, when Lyell firs insisted that long lines of inland cliffs had been formed, and grea valleys excavated, by the agencies which we still see at work.
Th direct action of changed conditions leads to definite or indefinit results.
Th exact lines of migration cannot be indicated.
Th existence at these and other distant points of the southern hemisphere, o species, which, though distinct, belong to genera exclusively confined t the south, is a more remarkable case.
Th explanation, no doubt, is that the littoral and sub-littoral deposits ar continually worn away, as soon as they are brought up by the slow an gradual rising of the land within the grinding action of the coast-waves.
Th extremities and inner margins of all the plates are frayed into stif bristles, which clothe the whole gigantic palate, and serve to strain o sift the water, and thus to secure the minute prey on which these grea animals subsist.
Th facts by no means seem to indicate that the greater or lesser difficulty o either grafting or crossing various species has been a special endowment although in the case of crossing, the difficulty is as important for th endurance and stability of specific forms as in the case of grafting it i unimportant for their welfare.
Th general sterility of crossed species may safely be looked at, not as  special acquirement or endowment, but as incidental on changes of a unknown nature in their sexual elements.
Th inhabitants of these hot lowlands would at the same time have migrated t the tropical and subtropical regions of the south, for the souther hemisphere was at this period warmer.

Th jaws, moreover, of the working ants of the several sizes differe wonderfully in shape, and in the form and number of the teeth.
Th justice of these remarks cannot, I think, be disputed.
Th larger and more dominant groups within each class thus tend to go o increasing in size, and they consequently supplant many smaller and feeble groups.

Th ostrich indeed inhabits continents, and is exposed to danger from which i cannot escape by flight, but it can defend itself, by kicking its enemies as efficiently as many quadrupeds.
Th palate is also covered with hard rounded knobs.
Th passage is narrow, and is roofed over by the column, so that a bee, i forcing its way out, first rubs its back against the viscid stigma and the against the viscid glands of the pollen-masses.
Th principle of selection I find distinctly given in an ancient Chines encyclopaedia.
Th process of diffusion would often be very slow, depending on climatal an geographical changes, on strange accidents, and on the gradua acclimatization of new species to the various climates through which the might have to pass, but in the course of time the dominant forms woul generally succeed in spreading and would ultimately prevail.
Th remark of that admirable palaeontologist, Edward Forbes, should never b forgotten, namely, that very many fossil species are known and named fro single and often broken specimens, or from a few specimens collected o some one spot.
Th representation of the groups as here given in the diagram on a fla surface, is much too simple.
Th resemblance is often wonderfully close, and is not confined to colour, bu extends to form, and even to the manner in which the insects hol themselves.
Th retina is wholly different, with an actual inversion of the elementa parts, and with a large nervous ganglion included within the membranes o the eye.
Th runt is a bird of great size, with long, massive beak and large feet; som of the sub-breeds of runts have very long necks, others very long wings an tails, others singularly short tails.
Th same result has followed from keeping together different varieties of th medicinal leech.
Th short-faced tumbler has a beak in outline almost like that of a finch; an the common tumbler has the singular inherited habit of flying at a grea height in a compact flock, and tumbling in the air head over heels.
Th slight variability of hybrids in the first generation, in contrast wit that in the succeeding generations, is a curious fact and deserve attention.
Th sterility is of all degrees, and is often so slight that the most carefu experimentalists have arrived at diametrically opposite conclusions i ranking forms by this test.
Th struggle for existence inevitably follows from the high geometrical rati of increase which is common to all organic beings.
Th tendency to reversion may often check or prevent the work; but as thi tendency has not prevented man from forming by selection numerous domesti races, why should it prevail against natural selection In the case of methodical selection, a breeder selects for some definit object, and if the individuals be allowed freely to intercross, his wor will completely fail.

Th whole organisation seems to have become plastic, and departs in a sligh degree from that of the parental type.

Tha species have a capacity for change will be admitted by all evolutionists but there is no need, as it seems to me, to invoke any internal forc beyond the tendency to ordinary variability, which through the aid o selection, by man has given rise to many well-adapted domestic races, an which, through the aid of natural selection, would equally well give ris by graduated steps to natural races or species.

That a girl so capable of being made everything good should be left in such hands, distressed her more and more.

That the manner in which she treated the dreadful crime committed by her brother and my sister (with whom lay the greater seduction I pretended not to say), but the manner in which she spoke of the crime itself, giving it every reproach but the right; considering its ill consequences only as they were to be braved or overborne by a defiance of decency and impudence in wrong; and last of all, and above all, recommending to us a compliance, a compromise, an acquiescence in the continuance of the sin, on the chance of a marriage which, thinking as I now thought of her brother, should rather be prevented than sought; all this together most grievously convinced me that I had never understood her before, and that, as far as related to mind, it had been the creature of my own imagination, not Miss Crawford, that I had been too apt to dwell on for many months past.

The Admiral and his daughter were both within, and both looked upon their visitor with more surprise than favour.
The Admiral delighted in the boy, Mrs. Crawford doted on the girl; and it was the lady's death which now obliged her protegee, after some months' further trial at her uncle's house, to find another home.
The Admiral has his faults, but he is a very good man, and has been more than a father to me.
The Admiral hated marriage, and thought it never pardonable in a young man of independent fortune.
The Admiral hates trouble, and scorns asking favours; and there are so many young men's claims to be attended to in the same way, that a friendship and energy, not very determined, is easily put by.

The barometer falling considerably below its average height is at once an indication that some considerable change is going to take place, and when it falls low, as for instance (in our climate) to near 29 inches, or below 2 inches, a gale is certain to follow.
The barometer falls, but not always, on the approach of thunder and lightning, or when the atmosphere is highly charged with electricity.
The barometer is rising when the mercurial column is lengthening; its upper surface being then, as in general, convex of rounded.
The barometer is said to be falling when the mercury in the tube is sinking, at which time its upper surface is sometimes concave of hollow.
The barometer shows whether the air is getting lighter or heavier, or is remaining in the same state.
The barometer tube, emptied of air, and filled with pure mercury, is turned down into a cup or cister containing the same fluid, which, feeling the weight of air, is s pressed by it as to balance a column of about thirty inches (more of less) in the tube, where no air presses on the top of the column.
The barometers intended to be tested are placed, together with  Standard, in an air-tight chamber, to which an air pump is applied, s that, by partially exhausting the air, the Standard can be made to read much lower than the lowest pressure to which marine barometers are likely to be exposed; and by compressing the air it can be made to read higher than the mercury ever stands at the level of the sea.

The facts given on th sterility of the illegitimate unions of dimorphic and trimorphic plants an of their illegitimate progeny, perhaps render it probable that some unknow bond in all cases connects the degree of fertility of first unions wit that of their offspring.
The facts now given on dimorphic and trimorphic plants are important because they show us, first, that the physiological test of lessene fertility, both in first crosses and in hybrids, is no safe criterion o specific distinction; secondly, because we may conclude that there is som unknown bond which connects the infertility of illegitimate unions wit that of their illegitimate offspring, and we are led to extend the sam view to first crosses and hybrids; thirdly, because we find, and this seem to me of especial importance, that two or three forms of the same specie may exist and may differ in no respect whatever, either in structure or i constitution, relatively to external conditions, and yet be sterile whe united in certain ways.

The newspapers - then, as always hitherto, almost entirely in the hands of the masters - clamoured to the Government for repressive measures; the rich citizens were enrolled as an extra body of police, and armed with bludgeons like them; many of these were strong, well-fed, full-blooded young men, and had plenty of stomach for fighting; but the Government did not dare to use them, and contented itself with getting full powers voted to it by the Parliament for suppressing any revolt, and bringing up more and more soldiers to London.
The newspapers next day all blazed into the fury of frightened people, and threatened the people, the Government, and everybody they could think of, unless 'order were at once restored.' A deputation of leading commercial people waited on the Government and told them that if they did not at once arrest the Committee of Public Safety, they themselves would gather a body of men, arm them, and fall on 'the incendiaries,' as they called them.

The words on scales of barometers should not be so much regarded for weather indications, as the rising or falling of the mercury; for, if it stand at Changeable, and then rise towards Fair, it presages change of wind or weather, though not so great, as if the mercury had risen higher; and, on the contrary, if the mercury stand above fair and then fall, it presages a change, though not to so great a degree as if it had stood lower: besides which, the direction, and force of wind are not in any way noticed.

There were no windows on the side opposite to the river, but arches below leading into chambers, one of which showed a glimpse of a garden beyond, and above them a long space of wall gaily painted (in fresco, I thought) with similar subjects to those of the frieze outside; everything about the place was handsome and generously solid as to material; and though it was not very large (somewhat smaller than Crosby Hall perhaps), one felt in it that exhilarating sense of space and freedom which satisfactory architecture always gives to an unanxious man who is in the habit of using his eyes.

These difficulties and objections may be classed under the following heads: First, why, if species have descended from other species by fin gradations, do we not everywhere see innumerable transitional forms?  Wh is not all nature in confusion, instead of the species being, as we se them, well defined Secondly, is it possible that an animal having, for instance, the structur and habits of a bat, could have been formed by the modification of som other animal with widely different habits and structure?  Can we believ that natural selection could produce, on the one hand, an organ of triflin importance, such as the tail of a giraffe, which serves as a fly-flapper and, on the other hand, an organ so wonderful as the eye Thirdly, can instincts be acquired and modified through natural selection? What shall we say to the instinct which leads the bee to make cells, an which has practically anticipated the discoveries of profoun mathematicians Fourthly, how can we account for species, when crossed, being sterile an producing sterile offspring, whereas, when varieties are crossed, thei fertility is unimpaired The two first heads will be here discussed; some miscellaneous objection in the following chapter; Instinct and Hybridism in the two succeedin chapters.

Thus, as I believe, species are multiplied and genera are formed.
Thus, as I believe, the most wonderful of all known instincts, that of th hive-bee, can be explained by natural selection having taken advantage o numerous, successive, slight modifications of simpler instincts; natura selection having, by slow degrees, more and more perfectly led the bees t sweep equal spheres at a given distance from each other in a double layer and to build up and excavate the wax along the planes of intersection.

Thus, as it seems to me, the manner in which single species and whol groups of species become extinct accords well with the theory of natura selection.
Thus, as it seems to me, the parallel, and, taken in a large sense simultaneous, succession of the same forms of life throughout the world accords well with the principle of new species having been formed b dominant species spreading widely and varying; the new species thu produced being themselves dominant, owing to their having had som advantage over their already dominant parents, as well as over othe species; and again spreading, varying, and producing new forms.

To be going so soon, sent for so kindly, sent for as a comfort, and with leave to take Susan, was altogether such a combination of blessings as set her heart in a glow, and for a time seemed to distance every pain, and make her incapable of suitably sharing the distress even of those whose distress she thought of most.
To be in the centre of such a circle, loved by so many, and more loved by all than she had ever been before; to feel affection without fear or restraint; to feel herself the equal of those who surrounded her; to be at peace from all mention of the Crawfords, safe from every look which could be fancied a reproach on their account.
To be listened to and borne with, and hear the voice of kindness and sympathy in return, was everything that could be done for her.
To be losing such pleasures was no trifle; to be losing them, because she was in the midst of closeness and noise, to have confinement, bad air, bad smells, substituted for liberty, freshness, fragrance, and verdure, was infinitely worse: but even these incitements to regret were feeble, compared with what arose from the conviction of being missed by her best friends, and the longing to be useful to those who were wanting her Could she have been at home, she might have been of service to every creature in the house.
To be neglected before one's time must be very vexatious; but it was entirely the mother's fault.

To be secure of a partner at first was a most essential good -  for the moment of beginning was now growing seriously near; and she so little understood her own claims as to think that if Mr. Crawford had not asked her, she must have been the last to be sought after, and should have received a partner only through a series of inquiry, and bustle, and interference, which would have been terrible; but at the same time there was a pointedness in his manner of asking her which she did not like, and she saw his eye glancing for a moment at her necklace, with a smile - she thought there was a smile - which made her blush and feel wretched.

To sum up on the origin of our domestic races of animals and plants.
To sum up, I believe that species come to be tolerably well-define objects, and do not at any one period present an inextricable chaos o varying and intermediate links:  first, because new varieties are ver slowly formed, for variation is a slow process, and natural selection ca do nothing until favourable individual differences or variations occur, an until a place in the natural polity of the country can be better filled b some modification of some one or more of its inhabitants.
To sum up, as far as the extreme intricacy of the subject permits, th circumstances favourable and unfavourable for the production of new specie through natural selection.

Tom Bertram must have been thought pleasant, indeed, at any rate; he was the sort of young man to be generally liked, his agreeableness was of the kind to be oftener found agreeable than some endowments of a higher stamp, for he had easy manners, excellent spirits, a large acquaintance, and a great deal to say; and the reversion of Mansfield Park, and a baronetcy, did no harm to all this.

Tom understood his father's thoughts, and heartily wishing he might be always as well disposed to give them but partial expression, began to see, more clearly than he had ever done before, that there might be some ground of offence, that there might be some reason for the glance his father gave towards the ceiling and stucco of the room; and that when he inquired with mild gravity after the fate of the billiard-table, he was not proceeding beyond a very allowable curiosity.

Variability  -  Individual differences  -  Doubtful species  -  Wide ranging much diffused, and common species, vary most  -  Species of the large genera in each country vary more frequently than the species of the smalle genera  -  Many of the species of the larger genera resemble varieties i being very closely, but unequally, related to each other, and in havin restricted ranges.
Variability i the same parts of the organisation has generally been taken advantage of i giving secondary sexual differences to the two sexes of the same species and specific differences to the several species of the same genus.
Variability is governed by many complex laws by correlated growth, compensation, the increased use and disuse of parts and the definite action of the surrounding conditions.
Variability is governed by many unknown laws, of whic correlated growth is probably the most important.
Variability is not actually caused by man; he only unintentionally expose organic beings to new conditions of life and then nature acts on th organisation and causes it to vary.
Variations neithe useful nor injurious would not be affected by natural selection, and woul be left either a fluctuating element, as perhaps we see in certai polymorphic species, or would ultimately become fixed, owing to the natur of the organism and the nature of the conditions.
Varieties generally hav much restricted ranges.

We are reminded by this latter fact of the extraordinary cases o Hippeastrum, Passiflora, etc., which seed much more freely when fertilise with the pollen of a distinct species than when fertilised with pollen fro the same plant.
We are so much accustomed to see a difference in structure between th embryo and the adult, that we are tempted to look at this difference as i some necessary manner contingent on growth.

We ca clearly see why the organic remains of closely consecutive formations ar closely allied; for they are closely linked together by generation.
We ca clearly see why the remains of an intermediate formation are intermediat in character.
We ca see how useful their production may have been to a social community o ants, on the same principle that the division of labour is useful t civilised man.
We ca sometimes see the reason why one tree will not take on another fro differences in their rate of growth, in the hardness of their wood, in th period of the flow or nature of their sap, etc.; but in a multitude o cases we can assign no reason whatever.
We ca thus also understand the fact that the Alpine plants of each mountain-rang are more especially related to the arctic forms living due north or nearl due north of them:  for the first migration when the cold came on, and th re-migration on the returning warmth, would generally have been due sout and north.
We came just here on a gang of men road-mending which delayed us a little; but I was not sorry for it; for all I had seen hitherto seemed a mere part of a summer holiday; and I wanted to see how this folk would set to on a piece of real necessary work.
We came on many groups both coming and going, or wandering in the edges of the wood.
We came presently into a large open space, sloping somewhat toward the south, the sunny site of which had been taken advantage of for planting an orchard, mainly, as I could see, of apricot-trees, in the midst of which was a pretty gay little structure of wood, painted and gilded, that looked like a refreshment-stall.
We can best gain some idea of past time by knowin the agencies at work; and learning how deeply the surface of the land ha been denuded, and how much sediment has been deposited.
We can carry up your things, or send some of the lads after them.
We can clearly discern this in the case of animals with simple habits.
We can clearly see how it is that all living and extinct forms ca be grouped together within a few great classes; and how the several member of each class are connected together by the most complex and radiatin lines of affinities.
We can clearly see why all th inhabitants of an archipelago, though specifically distinct on the severa islets, should be closely related to each other, and should likewise b related, but less closely, to those of the nearest continent, or othe source whence immigrants might have been derived.
We can clearly understand why a species when once lost should neve reappear, even if the very same conditions of life, organic and inorganic should recur.
We can dimly see why the competition should be most severe between allie forms, which fill nearly the same place in the economy of nature; bu probably in no one case could we precisely say why one species has bee victorious over another in the great battle of life.
We can further understand th singular fact remarked on by several observers that the productions o Europe and America during the later tertiary stages were more closel related to each other than they are at the present time; for during thes warmer periods the northern parts of the Old and New Worlds will have bee almost continuously united by land, serving as a bridge, since rendere impassable by cold, for the intermigration of their inhabitants.
We can here consider only a few cases; of these, some of th most difficult to explain are presented by fish.
We can not suppose that all the breeds were suddenly produce as perfect and as useful as we now see them; indeed, in many cases, we kno that this has not been their history.
We can now see that most of these claims were of themselves not worth either demanding or resisting; but they were looked on at that time as most important, and they were at least tokens of revolt against the miserable system of life which was then beginning to tumble to pieces.
We can perhap understand the apparently quicker rate of change in terrestrial and in mor highly organised productions compared with marine and lower productions, b the more complex relations of the higher beings to their organic an inorganic conditions of life, as explained in a former chapter.
We can se why, in islands, there should be some relation between the presence o mammals, in a more or less modified condition, and the depth of the se between such islands and the mainland.
We can see that any form which is represented b few individuals will run a good chance of utter extinction, during grea fluctuations in the nature or the seasons, or from a temporary increase i the number of its enemies.
We can see why characters derived from the embryo should be of equa importance with those derived from the adult, for a natural classificatio of course includes all ages.
We can see why there should be so striking a parallelism i the distribution of organic beings throughout space, and in thei geological succession throughout time; for in both cases the beings hav been connected by the bond of ordinary generation, and the means o modification have been the same.
We can see why throughout natur the same general end is gained by an almost infinite diversity of means for every peculiarity when once acquired is long inherited, and structure already modified in many different ways have to be adapted for the sam general purpose.
We can see why whol groups of organisms, as batrachians and terrestrial mammals, should b absent from oceanic islands, whilst the most isolated islands shoul possess their own peculiar species of aerial mammals or bats.
We can see why, if ther exist very closely allied or representative species in two areas, howeve distant from each other, some identical species will almost always there b found.
We can so far take a prophetic glanc into futurity as to foretell that it will be the common and widely sprea species, belonging to the larger and dominant groups within each class which will ultimately prevail and procreate new and dominant species.
We can thu understand why nature moves by graduated steps in endowing differen animals of the same class with their several instincts.
We can thus also understand the apparent paradox, tha the very same characters are analogical when one group is compared wit another, but give true affinities when the members of the same group ar compared together:  thus the shape of the body and fin-like limbs are onl analogical when whales are compared with fishes, being adaptations in bot classes for swimming through the water; but between the  the severa members of the whale family, the shape of the body and the fin-like limb offer characters exhibiting true affinity; for as these parts are so nearl similar throughout the whole family, we cannot doubt that they have bee inherited from a common ancestor.
We can thus understan the high importance of barriers, whether of land or water, in not onl separating but in apparently forming the several zoological and botanica provinces.
We can thus understand how it i that new species come in slowly and successively; how species of differen classes do not necessarily change together, or at the same rate, or in th same degree; yet in the long run that all undergo modification to som extent.
We can thus understand the concentration of related specie within the same areas; and how it is that under different latitudes, fo instance, in South America, the inhabitants of the plains and mountains, o the forests, marshes, and deserts, are linked together in so mysterious  manner, and are likewise linked to the extinct beings which formerl inhabited the same continent.
We can thus, as I infer from Professor Owen's interesting description o these parts, understand the strange fact that every particle of food an drink which we swallow has to pass over the orifice of the trachea, wit some risk of falling into the lungs, notwithstanding the beautifu contrivance by which the glottis is closed.
We can to a certain extent understand how it is that there is so muc beauty throughout nature; for this may be largely attributed to the agenc of selection.
We can understand how it is that all the forms of life, ancient and recent make together a few grand classes.
We can understand how it is that dominant forms which spread widely an yield the greatest number of varieties tend to people the world wit allied, but modified, descendants; and these will generally succeed i displacing the groups which are their inferiors in the struggle fo existence.
We can understand why a species or a group of species may depart from it allies, in several of its most important characteristics, and yet be safel classed with them.
We can understand why we value certain resemblance far more than others; why we use rudimentary and useless organs, or other of trifling physiological importance; why, in finding the relations betwee one group and another, we summarily reject analogical or adaptiv characters, and yet use these same characters within the limits of the sam group.
We can understand why, when a species ha once disappeared, it never reappears.
We can understand, from the continue tendency to divergence of character, why the more ancient a form is, th more it generally differs from those now living.
We can understand, on the above views, the very important distinctio between real affinities and analogical or adaptive resemblances.
We can, I think account for this fact only by looking at aberrant groups as forms whic have been conquered by more successful competitors, with a few member still preserved under unusually favourable conditions.
We can, I think, further understand the frequently abnormal character o our domestic races, and likewise their differences being so great i external characters, and relatively so slight in internal parts or organs.
We can, I think, see why the geological formations of each region ar almost invariably intermittent; that is, have not followed each other i close sequence.
We can, however, see in a genera manner that various causes might have interfered with the development of  long neck or proboscis.
We can, in short, see why nature is prodigal in variety though niggard in innovation.
We cannot attempt to defend Dr. Grant.
We cannot doubt that each structure is of use to each kind o squirrel in its own country, by enabling it to escape birds or beasts o prey, or to collect food more quickly, or, as there is reason to believe to lessen the danger from occasional falls.

We cannot hope to explain such facts, until we can say why on species and not another becomes naturalised by man's agency in a foreig land; why one species ranges twice or thrice as far, and is twice or thric as common, as another species within their own homes.

We cannot say why certai species and not others have migrated; why certain species have bee modified and have given rise to new forms, while others have remaine unaltered.
We cannot, for instance, suppose that i the embryos of the vertebrata the peculiar loop-like courses of th arteries near the branchial slits are related to similar conditions - in th young mammal which is nourished in the womb of its mother, in the egg o the bird which is hatched in a nest, and in the spawn of a frog unde water.
We care not how trifling a character may be - let it be the mere inflectio of the angle of the jaw, the manner in which an insect's wing is folded whether the skin be covered by hair or feathers - if it prevail throughou many and different species, especially those having very different habit of life, it assumes high value; for we can account for its presence in s many forms with such different habits, only by inheritance from a commo parent.

We hav seen that species at any one period are not indefinitely variable, and ar not linked together by a multitude of intermediate gradations, partl because the process of natural selection is always very slow, and at an one time acts only on a few forms; and partly because the very process o natural selection implies the continual supplanting and extinction o preceding and intermediate gradations.

We have also seen that it is the most flourishing or dominant species o the larger genera within each class which on an average yield the greates number of varieties, and varieties, as we shall hereafter see, tend t become converted into new and distinct species.
We have also seen that, as the specialisation of parts is a advantage to each being, so natural selection will tend to render th organisation of each being more specialised and perfect, and in this sens higher; not but that it may leave many creatures with simple and unimprove structures fitted for simple conditions of life, and in some cases wil even degrade or simplify the organisation, yet leaving such degraded being better fitted for their new walks of life.

We have reason to believe that species in a stat of nature are closely limited in their ranges by the competition of othe organic beings quite as much as, or more than, by adaptation to particula climates.
We have seen in the fourth chapter that the degree of differentiation an specialisation of the parts in organic beings, when arrived at maturity, i the best standard, as yet suggested, of their degree of perfection o highness.
We have seen in the last chapter that whole groups of species sometime falsely appear to have been abruptly developed; and I have attempted t give an explanation of this fact, which if true would be fatal to my views.
We have seen in this chapter how cautious we should be in concluding tha the most different habits of life could not graduate into each other; tha a bat, for instance, could not have been formed by natural selection fro an animal which at first only glided through the air.
We have seen that a species under new conditions of life may change it habits, or it may have diversified habits, with some very unlike those o its nearest congeners.
We have seen that in each country it is the species belonging to the large genera which oftenest present varieties or incipient species.
We have seen that in two beings widely remote from each other in th natural scale, organs serving for the same purpose and in externa appearance closely similar may have been separately and independentl formed; but when such organs are closely examined, essential differences i their structure can almost always be detected; and this naturally follow from the principle of natural selection.
We have seen that it is the common, the widely diffused, and widely rangin species, belonging to the larger genera within each class, which vary most and these tend to transmit to their modified offspring that superiorit which now makes them dominant in their own countries.
We have seen that man by selection can certainly produce grea results, and can adapt organic beings to his own uses, through th accumulation of slight but useful variations, given to him by the hand o Nature.
We have seen that the members of the same class, independently of thei habits of life, resemble each other in the general plan of thei organisation.
We have seen that the species which are most numerous in individuals hav the best chance of producing favourable variations within any given period.
We have seen that the sterility of hybrids which have their reproductiv organs in an imperfect condition, is a different case from the difficult of uniting two pure species, which have their reproductive organs perfect yet these two distinct classes of cases run to a large extent parallel.
We have seen that there is n infallible criterion by which to distinguish species and well-marke varieties; and when intermediate links have not been found between doubtfu forms, naturalists are compelled to come to a determination by the amoun of difference between them, judging by analogy whether or not the amoun suffices to raise one or both to the rank of species.

We may cease marvelling at the embryo of a air-breathing mammal or bird having branchial slits and arteries running i loops, like those of a fish which has to breathe the air dissolved in wate by the aid of well-developed branchiae.
We may conclude, from what we have seen of the intimate an complex manner in which the inhabitants of each country are bound together that any change in the numerical proportions of the inhabitants independently of the change of climate itself, would seriously affect th others.
We may doubt whether they have thus changed:  if the Megatherium, Mylodon Macrauchenia, and Toxodon had been brought to Europe from La Plata, withou any information in regard to their geological position, no one would hav suspected that they had co-existed with sea-shells all still living; but a these anomalous monsters co-existed with the Mastodon and Horse, it migh at least have been inferred that they had lived during one of the late tertiary stages.

We may often falsely attribute to correlated variation structures which ar common to whole groups of species, and which in truth are simply due t inheritance; for an ancient progenitor may have acquired through natura selection some one modification in structure, and, after thousands o generations, some other and independent modification; and these tw modifications, having been transmitted to a whole group of descendants wit diverse habits, would naturally be thought to be in some necessary manne correlated.

We may, however, according to M. Jourdain, descend even a step lower and find aggregates of pigment-cells apparently serving as organs of vision, without any nerves, and restin merely on sarcodic tissue.
We may, however, infer as probable from the consideration of dimorphic an trimorphic plants, that the sterility of distinct species when crossed an of their hybrid progeny, depends exclusively on the nature of their sexua elements, and not on any difference in their structure or genera constitution.

We mus not, however, push the foregoing argument too far, on account of th probable origin of some of our domestic animals from several wild stocks: the blood, for instance, of a tropical and arctic wolf may perhaps b mingled in our domestic breeds.
We must be cautious in attemptin to correlate as strictly contemporaneous two formations, which do no include many identical species, by the general succession of the forms o life.
We must by no means overlook the effects of the definite actio of changed conditions of life, of so-called spontaneous variations, whic seem to depend in a quite subordinate degree on the nature of th conditions, of the tendency to reversion to long-lost characters, of th complex laws of growth, such as of correlation, comprehension, of th pressure of one part on another, etc., and finally of sexual selection, b which characters of use to one sex are often gained and then transmitte more or less perfectly to the other sex, though of no use to the sex.

We must suppose the Melipona to have the power of formin her cells truly spherical, and of equal sizes; and this would not be ver surprising, seeing that she already does so to a certain extent, and seein what perfectly cylindrical burrows many insects make in wood, apparently b turning round on a fixed point.

We need not marvel at extinction; if we must marvel, let it b at our presumption in imagining for a moment that we understand the man complex contingencies on which the existence of each species depends.
We need not marvel at the sting of the bee, whe used against the enemy, causing the bee's own death; at drones bein produced in such great numbers for one single act, and being the slaughtered by their sterile sisters; at the astonishing waste of pollen b our fir-trees; at the instinctive hatred of the queen-bee for her ow fertile daughters; at ichneumonidae feeding within the living bodies o caterpillars; and at other such cases.

What can be more curious than that the hand of a man, formed for grasping that of a mole for digging, the leg of the horse, the paddle of th porpoise, and the wing of the bat, should all be constructed on the sam pattern, and should include similar bones, in the same relative positions How curious it is, to give a subordinate though striking instance, that th hind feet of the kangaroo, which are so well fitted for bounding over th open plains - those of the climbing, leaf-eating koala, equally well fitte for grasping the branches of trees - those of the ground-dwelling, insect o root-eating, bandicoots - and those of some other Australian marsupials - should all be constructed on the same extraordinary type, namely with th bones of the second and third digits extremely slender and enveloped withi the same skin, so that they appear like a single toe furnished with tw claws.

What can be more singular than the relation in cats between complet whiteness and blue eyes with deafness, or between the tortoise-shell colou and the female sex; or in pigeons, between their feathered feet and ski betwixt the outer toes, or between the presence of more or less down on th young pigeon when first hatched, with the future colour of its plumage; or again, the relation between the hair and the teeth in the naked Turkis dog, though here no doubt homology comes into play?  With respect to thi latter case of correlation, I think it can hardly be accidental that th two orders of mammals which are most abnormal in their dermal covering viz., Cetacea (whales) and Edentata (armadilloes, scaly ant-eaters, etc.) are likewise on the whole the most abnormal in their teeth, but there ar so many exceptions to this rule, as Mr. Mivart has remarked, that it ha little value.

What then checks a indefinite increase in the number of species?  The amount of life (I do no mean the number of specific forms) supported on an area must have a limit depending so largely as it does on physical conditions; therefore, if a area be inhabited by very many species, each or nearly each species will b represented by few individuals; and such species will be liable t extermination from accidental fluctuations in the nature of the seasons o in the number of their enemies.

When a character whic has been lost in a breed, reappears after a great number of generations the most probable hypothesis is, not that one individual suddenly take after an ancestor removed by some hundred generations, but that in eac successive generation the character in question has been lying latent, an at last, under unknown favourable conditions, is developed.
When a dotted line reaches one of the horizontal lines and is there marked by a small numbered letter, a sufficient amount o variation is supposed to have been accumulated to form it into a fairl well-marked variety, such as would be thought worthy of record in  systematic work.
When a group has once wholl disappeared, it does not reappear; for the link of generation has bee broken.
When a part has been developed in a extraordinary manner in any one species, compared with the other species o the same genus, we may conclude that this part has undergone a extraordinary amount of modification since the period when the severa species branched off from the common progenitor of the genus.
When a species has once disappeared from the face of the earth, we have n reason to believe that the same identical form ever reappears.
When a species, owing to highly favourable circumstances, increase inordinately in numbers in a small tract, epidemics - at least, this seem generally to occur with our game animals - often ensue; and here we have  limiting check independent of the struggle for life.
When a variation is of the slightest use to any being, we cannot tell ho much to attribute to the accumulative action of natural selection, and ho much to the definite action of the conditions of life.
When a young naturalist commences the study of a group of organisms quit unknown to him he is at first much perplexed in determining wha differences to consider as specific and what as varietal; for he know nothing of the amount and kind of variation to which the group is subject and this shows, at least, how very generally there is some variation.
When advanced up to any give point, there is no necessity, on the theory of natural selection, for thei further continued process; though they will, during each successive age have to be slightly modified, so as to hold their places in relation t slight changes in their conditions.
When an deviation of structure often appears, and we see it in the father an child, we cannot tell whether it may not be due to the same cause havin acted on both; but when among individuals, apparently exposed to the sam conditions, any very rare deviation, due to some extraordinary combinatio of circumstances, appears in the parent - say, once among several millio individuals - and it reappears in the child, the mere doctrine of chance almost compels us to attribute its reappearance to inheritance.
When any species becomes very rare close interbreeding will help to exterminate it; authors have thought tha this comes into play in accounting for the deterioration of the aurochs i Lithuania, of red deer in Scotland and of bears in Norway, etc.

When we no longer look at an organic being as  savage looks at a ship, as something wholly beyond his comprehension; whe we regard every production of nature as one which has had a long history when we contemplate every complex structure and instinct as the summing u of many contrivances, each useful to the possessor, in the same way as an great mechanical invention is the summing up of the labour, the experience the reason, and even the blunders of numerous workmen; when we thus vie each organic being, how far more interesting - I speak from experience - doe the study of natural history become A grand and almost untrodden field of inquiry will be opened, on the cause and laws of variation, on correlation, on the effects of use and disuse, o the direct action of external conditions, and so forth.

William, determined to make this last day a day of thorough enjoyment, was out snipe-shooting; Edmund, she had too much reason to suppose, was at the Parsonage; and left alone to bear the worrying of Mrs. Norris, who was cross because the housekeeper would have her own way with the supper, and whom she could not avoid though the housekeeper might, Fanny was worn down at last to think everything an evil belonging to the ball, and when sent off with a parting worry to dress, moved as languidly towards her own room, and felt as incapable of happiness as if she had been allowed no share in it.
